PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
To the Honourable The President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

2. Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14% of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
3. The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
4. This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that: 'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30% of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Mart Niklus
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to a question from me on 16 February this year in which I asked him to outline the three main elements of the Government's wages policy- a question to which I have not yet received an answer. I ask: Can the Minister now explain how the proposed wages freeze fits in with the Government's wages policy as enunciated by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations? In particular, I ask: As it is the Government's proposal to impose a wages freeze and as the Government is responsible for wages policy, what does the Government propose to do about wages policy at the expiration of the period of the freeze?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a request in similar terms yesterday. As I indicated, the very considerable difficulties that we face in the labour market in Australia today-the loss of employment and the growth in the number of people registering for employment-call for special measures. The Government has responded to the reality of what faces Australia. It is seeking co-operation from the State governments and, indeed, from the whole community in getting a wages pause which will do something to reduce the pressure on those businesses which are having to reduce their employment and which will do something to restore Australia's competitive position. I do not think many people in Australia need the sense of that proposition explained to them, even if the Leader of the Opposition does.

ANSWER.PARA: I was also questioned yesterday with respect to what will occur at the end of the freeze and questions were also addressed to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The point has been made by a number of Government spokesmen that it would not regard a catch-up in wages as being the correct thing to occur at the end of the freeze and the Government will pursue policies of wage moderation after the freeze for whatever period it is entered into.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question was this: What will be the Government's wages policy at the end of the freeze? That, of course, is a different matter from slogans about there being no catch-up and matters such as that. What will be the Government's wages policy at the end of the freeze?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our wages policy will have a number of elements. No doubt a central element will be to ensure that wage rises occur when the economy and business can afford them and when they do not result in the further destruction of employment in Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Sentor CHIPP-I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services much the same question as has been asked by Senator Missen. I have just had delivered to me a photostat copy of an advertisement appearing in today's local newspaper in the Flinders electorate. This contains a copy of the alleged telegram sent by Peter Reith to the Acting Prime Minister. Underneath that telegram, after three big blots, appears:
Democrats. support 'No Dams'
Peter Reith. supports 'No Dams'
Democrats. support 'Peter Reith'

If one looks carefully at the advertisement it can be seen that there is a small fullstop after the word 'Democrats', the words 'Peter Reith' and the word ' Democrats' again. As this is typical of the sort of dirty, filthy, misleading tricks that are played at election time, will the Minister make urgent representations to the Minister for Administrative Services to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act so that misleading or untruthful advertising can be barred at election times and be made illegal for political parties to engage in, just as soap manufacturers or toilet paper manufacturers are precluded from issuing misleading or untruthful advertising?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp has made a number of extravagant assertions. As far as I know he is the only honourable senator in possession of a copy of the advertisement.
—Do you doubt his word?

—Not at all. I just have not seen the advertisement myself. I feel it should be referred as it is to the Minister for his attention directly. I think that, on the information provided by Senator Chipp, we need to observe one or two things. First of all, the advertisement refers to the support of the Australian Democrats for Peter Reith. All of us know that there is in this country the system of voting known as preferential voting. Therefore, there is concern that people who indicate preferences for individual candidates should do so in proper order of preference. For that reason, clearly the word 'support'-I am not giving any kerbside opinion-has a fairly wide interpretation within that system. Nevertheless, having said that, if Senator Chipp is prepared to supply a copy of the advertisement, I will refer it to the Minister for Administrative Services for review and to see whether anything further ought to be done.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will we ever reach a point in Question Time when a Minister can give a straight answer to a simple question? I simply asked whether the Minister agreed that this was a misleading advertisement and whether he would agree to take the matter to the Minister for Administrative Services with a recommendation that the Commonwealth Electoral Act be amended to make it illegal for political parties or political candidates to enter into misleading or untruthful advertising. The fact is that the Australian Democrats 'how to vote' card has been distributed to letter boxes since last weekend. The card clearly shows that we have followed the past practice of not supporting either candidate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp has made some further assertions about this matter. I have asked him to provide a copy of the advertisement. As far as I know, he is the only one in possession of it. I have said that I will refer the matter to the Minister. I undertake to do so.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Social Security to suggestions by the Opposition over a period that the Commonwealth Government is more interested in prosecuting persons who are in breach of the Social Services Act than offenders under the Income Tax Assessment Act. I ask the Minister merely to comment on that allegation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were some allegations of the sort mentioned by the honourable senator. I must say that I found the allegations disturbing and had them checked. The fact of the matter is, of course, the exact reverse to the suggestions which were made. In fact, if one looks at the record of the Government with respect to prosecutions under the Income Tax Assessment Act as against the Social Services Act one will find that there is a very wide discrepancy in favour of prosecutions under the Income Tax Assessment Act. In one year 57,842 prosecutions were made under the Income Tax Assessment Act and in the same year 2,042 prosecutions were made under the social security legislation. Clearly, there is a massive imbalance in favour of the prosecuting of tax defaulters rather than social security defaulters.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the number of people involved on a per hundred basis, the figures are again illustrative of where the emphasis lies. We pay social security benefits and pensions to over 2.3 million Australians. If one looks at the number of prosecutions to clients one will find that there is one prosecution for every 1,126 clients receiving pensions and benefits. As far as taxpayers are concerned, there is one prosecution for every 103 taxpayers, so that it appears that there is about a one per cent chance of a taxpayer being prosecuted as things stand. There is no basis for the sort of statement which was made by Opposition representatives. I can only say that in both areas it is the concern of the Government that the law should be obeyed and that it should take suitable steps to make sure that that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the fact that the Government has admitted that the deficit will blow out by 50 per cent and that the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury, in a letter of which large sections were published in a newspaper on 25 November, has substantially dissociated himself and his Department from this year's Budget, will the Government supply to the Senate a revised estimate of receipts and expenditure for 1982-83, prepared by the Treasury and signed by Mr Stone, so that the Senate can be assured that the estimates really are those of the Treasury and not the more rubbery estimates of Ministers or of people Mr Stone described as 'the more meretricious players who flit across the private ministerial advisory stage'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The succinct answer to the honourable senators question is that the unemployment figures incorporated in the Budget were supplied by the authority of the Treasury; they were Treasury figures. Cabinet asked the Treasury to confirm those figures. So the basis of the Budget is Treasury figures. In no way at all can that be gainsaid. Since the rest of the question was directed to the Treasurer, I will refer it to him. But I make it abundantly clear that the basis on which the Budget was set up in terms of unemployment was the unemployment figures supplied by the Department of the Treasury, and the Department of the Treasury will confirm that.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is Senator Carrick now saying that the extracts which the newspapers have published from the letter signed by Mr Stone are in fact fakes and are not a true record of what Mr Stone implied in his letter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not on the circulation list for letters of the Secretary to the Treasury, so I do not know whether the letter exists or what its content is. I have not said that. I will repeat what I have said because Senator McLaren needs to know it. Senator McLaren's question was based on the assumption that the deficit is blowing out because of false figures for unemployment and on the assumption that the false figures were based on Cabinet figures and not on Treasury figures. That is my understanding.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. Senator McLaren asked a supplementary question and the Leader is answering it. I ask that he be given the opportunity to do so--
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Nowhere in my question did I mention unemployment. The Leader of the Government is misquoting me. He is misleading the Senate.
—There is no point of order.

—The blowout of the Budget deficit comes essentially from two matters. One is the drought relief and the other is the unemployment figures. As the question was related to the figures supplied for the Estimates, I repeat that the unemployment figures which have enlarged and which have caused the Budget deficit blowout were the figures provided by the Department of the Treasury. I repeat that the basis of this Budget was the figures supplied by the Treasury.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. As the drought is continuing and particularly in view of the importance of the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme for the provision of irrigation water and electricity generation for New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory, I ask the Minister whether he can advise the present and the future positions with regard to the water storages of the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have recently been advised of the position by my Department and by the Snowy Mountains people and the position is of considerable interest to all Australians. The inflow to the Snowy-Murray development and Upper Tumut works for the period 1 May to 31 October was 594 gigalitres. This was the lowest inflow ever recorded. I repeat that this was the lowest inflow ever recorded. The previous lowest inflow was 620 gigalitres. As at 30 October of this year the storages of the Snowy scheme were at 33 per cent of total capacity. If the drought conditions continue and inflows remain at a low level Snowy storage could be below 15 per cent of capacity by 30 April next year. Release of notified entitlements of water has been requested and is essential for irrigation. The flexibility of the Snowy scheme in providing both water and electricity is likely to be limited over the coming months. If inflows less than the minimum recorded continue the situation will obviously become quite serious towards the end of next year.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said earlier in response to questions by, I believe, a number of honourable senators, the Australian aid program does not necessarily support the internal affairs of the countries to which it is directed. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Australian Capital Territory aware that, as late as last week, the water hyacinth, the scourge of the world's fresh waterways, could be purchased legally in Canberra? Will the Minister take prompt action to see that this attractive-looking water plant, which continues to choke the world's rivers, is immediately withdrawn from sale in the Australian Capital Territory, and future sales in the Territory regulated against so that it cannot be accidentally discharged into Australia's river system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem posed by the water hyacinth has been raised in this place on a number of occasions. I well remember our former colleague, Senator Webster, speaking with much erudition and at great length on that subject. I am not aware that the water hyacinth is being sold within the Australian Capital Territory but will, as a matter of urgency, bring that fact to the attention of the authorities. I believe that all honourable senators, especially those from South Australia, would be concerned about any possible extension of water hyacinth infestation in the higher reaches of the Darling River and its tributaries lest it extend further into the River Murray system.

—Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware that large sections of the business community, who probably live in fear of the remote possibility of a price pause being imposed, have taken the initiative by increasing prices by as much as 40 per cent? Does the Minister approve of this tactic? If not, what action will he or the Government take to eliminate such dishonest activity by white collar operators in the business community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government of course would not approve of such practices and I invite Senator Keeffe to give me chapter and verse of specific instances that come to his attention. I will ensure that the details are directed to the State government concerned. State governments have sovereign powers over price control and, given case, chapter and verse, the relevant government can act accordingly. I wish to make it abundantly clear that all six States have power to impose price controls. That fact has been noted and accepted by them in recent days in relation to petrol pricing and other matters. If any honourable senator feels that such an abuse is being practised he can either give me details for transmission to the State concerned or transmit them himself. I am sure that the relevant State government would be keenly interested .

—I ask a supplementary question. I take it from what the Minister has said that he has no authority to take the initiatives himself in relation to the application of pressure on State governments to do the job.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Keeffe could not have understood what I said. I said that if he will please give me the specific instances I will examine them . If they are, as I understand them to be, matters that come under State jurisdiction I will ensure that they are transmitted to the State concerned for action. Senator Keeffe must know that the Commonwealth does not have those powers, that they are State powers. But in any case, I invite Senator Keeffe to give me those specific instances.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. With what appears to be the development of an open trade war between the European Economic Community and the United States of America, together with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks finishing in a chaotic situation, what then is Australia's future, particularly in regard to markets for its primary products? In this free-for-all for markets, how does the Government see Australia's future trade, particularly with its neighbours in this region of the world? Is it a fact that the friction between nations is being fuelled by the world recession? Is this likely to bring about further collapse in trade arrangements between nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Prime Minister, upon his return from the Geneva meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, expressed the dismay of the Government, and I think of all Australians, at the breakdown of discussions, the breakdown of consensus within the free world and the move towards putting further barriers around individual countries, particularly member countries of the European Economic Community. Therefore, as to Senator Kilgariff's question, there is no doubt that as a result trade prospects for Australian products are more uncertain than they have been for a long time. If a trade war does develop across a range of agricultural products, countries such as Australia and New Zealand could suffer.

ANSWER.PARA: We are also concerned about the real prospect of bilateralism-that is, country to country agreements-and we view with apprehension the results of private talks between the United States of America and the European Community which are scheduled to take place next week. This is the very antithesis of the freeing of world trade. It is important to keep in mind that jobs can be created only if we can have the ability to trade. We will undertake all possible actions to prevent moves towards bilateral agreements. Clearly, some countries are reluctant to adhere to GATT and are unwilling to resist their protectionist pressures. It is, therefore, difficult, even pointless, to continue discussions in that regard.

The Government's basic trade objective is an open multilateral system for trade and payments. This is the only way to maintain prospects for economic growth. An inward looking economic situation would entail far too great a cost for Australia's standard of living. Australia has, over its history, depended on trade for its well being. It has depended upon its ability to move outwards into world markets to earn money to create the living standards of the Australian people. We have, therefore, pursued a policy with the rest of the world to overcome the kinds of disabilities that we have seen in the past, which have destroyed employment in various countries and which have brought in fact a worse recession to the world. So we regret very much the breakdown of trade. However, because Australia lives within the Pacific, and particularly within the western Pacific, it is inevitable that more of Australia's trade will turn to that region. To the extent that much of our trade moves that way now we are not so likely to be affected by the EEC decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, relates to the seeking of overseas finance by the Western Australian Government for the proposed sugar industry in Western Australia. Will the Government give an unqualified guarantee that it will not allow Korean capital to enter this country to finance an Ord River sugar industry as proposed by the Western Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any proposal for foreign capital to come into this country must, first of all, come before the Foreign Investment Review Board. It must meet guidelines and it must be subject to government policies. I do not know of the nature of any such proposal, other than what is contained in newspaper reports at the moment. Until some firm proposals are made and some details given on this matter then, of course, the Government cannot comment on it. I turn now to the question of sugar. It is true that world prices for sugar at this moment are low and that Australia is in a difficult situation and has a quantitative limitation on its exports. All these matters in the end must be viewed. I think we should wait first of all to see what is the nature and substance of any submission before we sit in judgment on it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN UNIVERSITIES: EMPLOYMENT OF OVERSEAS ACADEMICS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education. Is the Minister aware of disquiet on the part of applicants for tenured positions at Australian universities and that some universities are giving undue preference to applicants with overseas qualifications over Australian-qualified applicants? For example, at Macquarie University, of four lecturer positions recently created by the disestablishment of seven tutorial positions in the School of Behavioural Sciences, two of the four positions went to overseas applicants whereas the seven tutoring positions had been held by Australians. Is it a fact that there is no reciprocity for Australian graduates in the United Kingdom or the United States? Is it a fact that Australian doctor of philosophy graduates would find it impossible to find jobs at British or American institutions because of unstated barriers raised by the slightly different graduate school systems? Is it a fact that Canada insists that such jobs go to Canadians? Does Australia's immigration policy require Australian universities to satisfy the criterion that jobs in Australia should go to Australians who are qualified for them before they are offered to non-Australians? Is the Minister satisfied that this criterion is as stringently enforced in the case of academic jobs as it is for other categories of employment? Will the Minister agree to make representations to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to ensure that Australian universities are required to abide by our immigration laws as strictly as are other employers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of what happened recently at Macquarie University but I do have some information about this matter. I believe it has been the subject of some consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts in its report on the tenure of employment of academics. I understand that the Committee did refer to this question. Essentially, universities are self-governing institutions and the appointment of staff is a matter for the university authorities themselves. For reasons which concern proper institutional autonomy it might be difficult to interfere too much in the way in which the universities approach the employment of their academic staff. I understand though that the Senate Standing Committee in its consideration of this matter did ascertain that a significant proportion of academics in Australian institutions is traditionally recruited from overseas. I understand that, for the year up to April 1977, 50 per cent of all the new academic appointments were from overseas. I suppose that, if one looked at transfers within universities in Australia and took those numbers out, the percentage of new recruitments would be higher than 50 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that universities advertise internationally. Senator Martin's question referred to the constraints which apply to universities employing overseas applicants while there may be suitable Australians. I am advised by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that permanent migrants have to meet normal migrant criteria. That means they have to have an employment nomination, among other things. I understand that the Department does insist that the university has to try to employ local persons first. So the rules are clear. Senator Martin asked what the rules were. She also asked whether they were being properly enforced. I understand that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic affairs does carry out checks to see that the regulations are being applied properly.

The Senate Standing Committee had some comments to offer on the way in which we should approach this matter. It reported that the Australian academic community would not wish to see artificial barriers imposed on international competition. I think it was looking to the very best standards of participation in our universities and our colleges. It also recommended that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission examine whether unreasonable restrictions are placed upon Australian academics overseas and make that known to the Government in case it needs to take it up in a policy sense or by way of bilateral negotiations. The Government is still considering its response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee. It will be making a statement to the Senate in due course. The matters which I have raised and which were the subject of Senator Martin's question will be among the considerations which the Government will have before it at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister will recall that in 1967 the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission abolished the basic wage and margins concept and introduced the total wage. This was done at the behest of the government of the day and of the employers, against opposition from me and others. Is it not a fact that in recent years increases on economic grounds for movements in the consumer price index have been generally applied as a percentage of total wages? For example, with a 5 per cent increase a person earning $200 a week gets $10 a week and a person earning $500 a week gets $25 a week to cover the same increase in prices. Would not a restoration of the two- tiered system provide a structure wherein the blow-out of wages can more readily be contained, lower wage earners can be protected more adequately and margins for skills and responsibility can be more visibly delineated? In the lead-up to the Premiers Conference, will the Minister have regard to this evident fact and bring to the Premiers Conference a recommendation for the restoration of the two -tiered structure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator raised a very significant matter. It is true, as he said, that in more recent years increases have been granted as a percentage of total wages. That policy, of course, has the effect which he has described. I have often heard it defended in terms of maintaining margins for skill, and so on, although the point made by the honourable senator in his question is that it may indeed have a reverse effect. I will refer the suggestion to Mr Macphee. I would not expect that very substantial suggestion for change to be part of the agenda, but I will draw it to the Minister's attention today and seek his consideration of it.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Has the Minister noted comments made recently by the Chairman of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Dr Wild, in which he pointed to Australian manufacturing industry's lack of entrepreneurship to capitalise on research, development and new scientific ideas in order to generate economic benefits? Is the Government concerned at this apparent unwillingness by private industry to engage in private industrial research and development? Does the Government believe that industry's reluctance to apply for less than half of the 1981-82 allocation under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act reflects a true lack of enterprising spirit, or is it related to difficulties that firms are encountering when applying for government grants? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly it is an undeniable fact that Australian industry proportionately subscribes to a much lower level of industrial research and development than occurs in many countries, particularly those with which Australia could be compared. As I understand it, there was a fairly wide discussion on this matter in Senate Estimates Committee F. I am told that in September of this year an explanation was given to the Senate Estimates Committee, with regard to the Department of Science and Technology and the introduction of the Act in June 1981, of the provisions which require companies to provide security against advances of payment for approved project expenditure that were proving more restricting than had been expected. ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jessop also mentioned the matter of taxation concessions. This has been raised on a number of occasions, most recently in the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry and report into certain budgetary assistance to industry. As I am advised, taxation incentives are of little assistance to new companies or companies, particularly the numbers of them at present, which have a very low level of profitability or no tax liabilities. They receive no assistance by way of tax deductibility for any expenditure they may incur in the way of industrial research and development. However, the question of Senator Jessop raises a couple of matters of policy that I will refer to the Minister concerned and see whether he has a response to make to them.

—Does the Minister representing the Treasurer not agree that the Government's proposed wages freeze will amount to a return to a form of centralised wage fixing? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. I refer him to the proposed National Crimes Commission, which has been effectively proposed without the active participation , enthusiasm, co-operation or good will of the governments of the States or the Northern Territory, but is, rather, based on the American crimes commission system. Is the Minister aware that the Mafia and organised crime are alive and well in America in spite of the American crimes commissions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government certainly would not claim that organised crime is peculiar to Australia. It is a matter of great regret to us that the sort of organised criminal activity that we have heard of in other countries should be found to be alive and well in this country. There is a variety of methods of attack on organised crime. One of the chores of the Attorney-General was to examine the different approaches which are adopted around the world. He visited the United States some time ago. He saw the work of the crimes commissions which operate in a number of States and, of course, the work of grand juries, which present a quite different approach to the lead-up to prosecution of criminal matters in the United States. I think what is said by Mr Costigan is unfortunately probably true: No matter how effective the mechanisms that we put in place, it is likely that there will continue to be some elements of organised crime in this country. I suppose that is true of the United States as well.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that we have had a lamentable failure to come to grips with organised crime. There have been too many reports which have been followed by too little action. It is the Government's view that there is a Commonwealth responsibility to ensure that in areas of clear Commonwealth legal responsibility we should have this additional tool to strike at what is evident now in our community, namely, crime which occurs not on an episodic basis but on an organised and regular basis in the nature of a current and continuing business. I think there is widespread concern in the community about the existence of organised crime. That has been evident in a number of ways. I believe that there will be a general welcoming of this Commonwealth initiative to come to grips with it.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the French Socialist Government of Mitterrand, on coming to office some 18 months ago, introduced a strongly inflationary program similar to that which has recently been advocated by the Australian Labor Party and its leader? Is it a fact that the French program resulted in two devaluations of the franc, galloping inflation and massive increases in unemployment? Has this program now been replaced by a deflationary policy involving an austerity program much more severe than that of the United Kingdom and that of Ronald Reagan and much more severe than would have been needed if the French had not previously adopted an inflationary policy? Is it a fact that the current austerity program adopted by the French has in effect marked the beginning of the erosion of real wages in France? Is it designed to encourage private enterprise to become competitive with the rest of Europe? Has the Australian Government learnt any lessons from the French experiment? If so, what lessons has it learnt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the world knows that the Mitterrand Government came to power on the strength of policies which were enormously expansionary and calculated to inflate enormously the money supply and the deficit. The world- wide comment was that that would inevitably lead to severe inflation and consequent severe unemployment. Indeed, those predictions came abundantly true. As Senator Lewis said, France suffered very severe inflation, devaluation and unemployment. The result has been that France, in common with other countries of Europe and elsewhere, has faced the reality that the only way in which to come to grips with inflation is to tackle costs. The main ingredient of costs is the cost of labour. France is now tackling the cost of labour and has brought about a lowering of the upsurge of wages and a steadying of inflation. It is true that the policies it has pursued in order to rectify its economy's former defects are now more severe than should have been necessary in the first place. There is a very real lesson to be learnt here. Clearly, any government which pursues expansionary policies by deliberately inflating the money supply will not create jobs but will produce inflation and unemployment. The road back is to do what the rest of the free world is now doing-endeavouring to bear down on costs by getting wage stability. That is precisely the policy now being advocated by this Government for the Premiers Conference next week.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. This Government's answer to fighting inflation has been to create unemployment and impose high direct and indirect taxes. Its rein on inflation has been a miserable failure. As the Minister is so fond of the trite remark, ' One man's wage rise is another man's job', I ask him whether it is not also true that a demand for goods and services-that is, increased spending power-creates jobs. Is this Government happy to see a state of stagnation in the economy and despair in the community? Has it not practised anti-growth policies, including wage restraint, for the past seven years and achieved only one result-that the economy has come to a complete stop? I further ask the Minister whether the Liberal Party has an engine driver in its ranks to give the Government better economic advice than it is getting now. The Minister may recall that the best Treasurer Australia ever had-at a time of great national stress-was an engine driver and Prime Minister named Ben Chifley.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That question certainly reveals that Senator Elstob does not regard Mr Hayden or Mr Crean as quality Treasurers from the Australian Labor Party. He denigrated Mr Crean in his question, in that it was Mr Crean who invented the phrase, which is abundantly true, that one man's wage rise is another man's job. It is no wonder that Senator Elstob seeks engine drivers. He would naturally leave out Mr Hayden because there is division in the Labor Party now and because Mr Hayden as Treasurer was spot on when he stated in his last Budget that increasing the money supply by simply inflating the deficit created unemployment. Let me get that straight. I reject the rhetoric of the opening part of Senator Elstob's question. The Government's policies have not created unemployment. Unemployment in this country has been created by a world recession . That is acknowledged by all authoritative commentators. The fact is that the whole world has been in grave recession, a creeping recession, for the last nine to 10 years. The world recession has resulted in--
—I thought it was the trade unions-plus wages.

—Mr President, if Senator Button wants to interject he has my invitation to get up and make a statement. An Australian Labor Party, led by people such as Senator Button, that is devoid of any policy, divided in its leadership struggles between Hayden and Hawke and torn with dissension, can do only one thing and that is to have its members interject continuously during the answer to a question in this place, to try to stop the message getting through. Senator Button will not succeed in that.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat, because we have had a classic example of what the Labor Party is trying to do, that the fact of the matter is that both Mr Crean and Mr Hayden as Treasurers worked on the assumption that one man's pay rise was another man's job. Senator Elstob has ignored them because it does not suit his purpose today. The fact of the matter is that this recession is acknowledged as having been brought on by overseas recession which has meant that trade is shrinking in Australia. The way out is the way that all other countries in the free world have been seeking to follow. I repeat that the Labor Party finds itself more and more out on a limb as the only group now that is rejecting the idea of wage restraint as the primary function in getting costs down and fighting inflation. So the basis of Senator Elstob's question is entirely false.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Scott proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The serious position for Australia and the world resulting from the failure of last week's GATT Ministers' meeting in Geneva.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to open the discussion this afternoon on what I really believe is, as the matter of public importance states :

SPEECH.PARA: The serious position for Australia and the world resulting from the failure of last week's GATT Ministers' meeting in Geneva.

There can be no doubt that the failure of that meeting to come to perhaps more positive determinations-not entirely because of the attitude of the European Economic Community but at least significantly because of that attitude-does hold great problems for all major trading countries, in particular for Australia, and in even more particular circumstances for the developing countries. It might be appropriate to recall that this ministerial meeting of the GATT was the first such meeting since 1973. It might also be worth recalling something of the structure of the GATT and its objectives. I shall be very brief in dealing with that field.

Basically the GATT is a system of trading rules that developed out of the economic chaos of the 1930s. It was with that behind us that the world saw fit in January 1948 to form the GATT. At that stage the nations that comprised the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade numbered only 23 and of the 23 original members Australia was one. Membership has grown since 1948 to consist now of 86 contracting members. A further 32 members are really de facto members and abide by and apply the rules of the GATT. A further feature is that this organisation' s membership is responsible for significantly in excess of 80 per cent of total world trade. GATT is an important body. It has a very clear objective and a clear contribution to make to establishing trading circumstances that may well see better use of the world's natural resources, both material and manpower. I do not believe that the fact that the Economic Community could not come to a final solution that was satisfactory to the bulk of its membership is an insuperable obstacle. The Economic Community may well change its stance, albeit gradually. In doing so it would, one would hope, seek to stop the possibility of a drift of world trade into the establishment of varying inward looking trading blocs. The European Community is significantly an inward looking bloc. The result of that sort of attitude would inevitably be, I fear, a term of trade warfare.

Trade warfare is a form of warfare like most others from which there are very few, if any, victors. The trade warfare in which massive subsidisation occurs and an unnatural distribution of the world's products likewise occurs is destructive to even the powerful operator who is capable of subsidising to the extent necessary. But in the case of Australia and many other such trading countries around the world, certainly in the case of nations of the developing world, it would be a disaster. It is my hope, indeed my belief, that the European Community will recognise the sort of devastation that could occur from a policy that would develop a number of trading blocks around the world. That would be the aftermath of trade warfare.

It is somewhat extraordinary that we should find these constant limiting circumstances to world trade at a time when the capacity of the world to trade is theoretically and practically greater than it has ever been. Man's capacity to communicate by land, sea and air is so fast, so all-consuming, that the basic requirements for international trade are much more effective and efficient today than ever in man's history. The world's history holds many examples of the dire consequences of the failure to follow a realistic international trading policy. It has been said more than once that if butter does not cross the frontiers guns will. Regrettably, history holds a great number of incidents from which that has been the result.

I find the European Economic Community's attitude quite understandable within its own context. Insofar as it has set up the Common Agricultural Policy to enable it to ensure the supply of foodstuffs and essential materials, that is a reasonable and proper attitude, particularly with a view to the history of Europe. Over the decades-indeed, even over the centuries-Europe has constantly been concerned about a situation which may well see its being cut off from its basic and essential supplies. As a reaction to that part of history it developed the Common Agricultural Policy, albeit at enormous cost to its own citizens. It established a better situation for its primary industry producers in particular. I believe that is relevant to the problem and the great argument. As I said, I can perfectly understand the establishment of the Common Agricultural Policy. I hope and believe that ultimately, as a result of various sets of circumstances, the European Economic Community will see fit to admit the goods of the more economic producers around the world. Of course, they include Australia in a significant field of international trade.

Having said that I understand fully that situation, I must point out further that the ultimate result of the Common Agricultural Policy as it has existed to this time has been to produce, because of the attractiveness of the subsidisation, quite massive subsidised surpluses. These surpluses have been unleashed on the free markets around the world at prices with which the genuine, bona fide producers in international trading are unable to compete. This has developed what I believe is a distortion of and damage of great proportion to many of the world's economies. At this stage I take only one instance of the involvement of subsidised masses in the normal areas of international trade: The sugar industry is in dire straits in many parts of the world today. The facts are that for the five years ending in 1977 the European Economic Community pumped into the markets of international trade about 800,000 to 850,000 tonnes of sugar annually. Yet last year the European Economic Community pumped into those free markets around the world no less than 5.3 million tonnes of sugar-an increase of something like 500 per cent-whilst the member states of the International Sugar Agreement received an increase of 3 per cent in their contribution. That is the sort of tragic situation-particularly in sugar production, which is so important to Australia and immensely important to the developing world-which totally distorts the international trading position and which certainly ensures the uneconomic use of the world's resources.

I do not want it to be thought for a moment that I have not a full and proper regard for the value of, and contribution made by, a protection policy to this economy and to many other economies around the world. In infant industries, and for many years beyond infancy, protection has played an important part. It has, in the Australian circumstance, enabled us to develop a much more versatile and complex economy than we would ever have had otherwise. The problem really is as to how far that measure of protection must go. Indeed, when it reaches the point at which it involves the establishment and maintenance of totally uneconomic entities in the industrial and commercial world it becomes a load on the country that supports it. But I reiterate that protection, in a reasonable and responsible measure, has made a great contribution to the development of a complex Australian economy and a great contribution to the development of job opportunities for Australians over a very wide range of industrial and commercial activity.

Australia must be concerned with the degree of freedom of international trade because, as much as or probably more than any other country on earth, it needs overseas markets. It needs them to such an extent that some 65 per cent of its grain must be exported. Some 50 to 60 per cent of its meat, even at today's production levels, must find a market overseas. For wool, 95 per cent of its market must lie overseas. Since Australia has a population of only 15 million, as against a population of 300 million in the European Economic Community, 300 million or so in North America, and enormous populations in Japan, China and so on, it cannot be inward looking. It must be able to move out into areas of legitimate international trade. Consequently, we must try-as was tried at the GATT meeting and hopefully will yet succeed, although maybe not in the next week or month-to initiate on a reciprocal basis a pause, a standstill, in protection. Indeed, when from time to time, as employment and the state of the economy warrant, see fit to reduce the protection barriers around our economy, we must ensure that such reduction is matched by reciprocal action on the part of our great trading partners.

Our mining and processing industries, our advances in sophisticated technology as a result of scientific research and discovery in engineering, medicine and so forth, have an enormous and exciting potential. They could form the bases of new and exciting industries, but such industries will not be viable unless the trading circumstance is much freer than has been the tendency in recent years.

Our tourist industry also possesses enormous and exciting potential, yet finds it extraordinarily hard to compete with its subsidised competitors. We have to be aware of these factors and, unquestionably, ensure that such subsidies do not reach such proportions as to deny the capacity of industry to develop in its own economic area. I have mentioned that tariffs, protection and trade barriers have had a part to play in the development of a complex and total economy. However, I must make the point that in excess these factors ultimately will contribute to unemployment. I say that because increased costs and prices, inflation and concurrent balance of payments and deficit problems must produce an uncertainty and a lack of confidence in the economy which ultimately can only contribute to a lessening of profitability and the employment potential of this great country. Therefore, in the long term we must continue to search for reciprocal reductions in trade barriers around the world. We must develop an education system that will produce the type of person necessary for a technologically based Australian economy. The Government is aware of this as has been shown by the emphasis on school to work transition, technical and further education-the real development of which has increased every year of this Government's occupancy of office-and apprenticeships.

I want to comment once again on the severity of the current drought which is ravaging Australia. The problems created are very similar to those that would evolve from a failure to gain and maintain access to existing and growing markets for efficiently produced Australian goods. The drought is widespread, covering four States in eastern Australia. It is the most severe drought we have ever known. Unfortunately, it has come at the conclusion of a five-year period of which three to four years have been drought years. Consequently, fodder is at an absolute minimum. The drought has thrown into stark light the total interdependence of industry and commerce in Australia, particularly in rural Australia, today. No longer can we talk of 120,000, 130,000 or 140,000 farmers being affected. Indeed, more than three million Australians in virtually every walk of life are being drastically affected by a drought of this proportion. Primary industry produces practically 50 per cent of Australia's export income.

The severity of the drought, causing as it has across a very wide range of industry and commerce a tragic loss of jobs to which there is no simple solution , can be equalled by the severity of a trade war or trading bloc concept as a result of which Australia may well lose some of its very necessary markets at any time in the future. The drought, because of its relevance to the total Australian economy, is part and parcel of the trading situation, just as it is part and parcel of the weather situation. I conclude my remarks by mentioning that the holding and gradual lowering of tariff barriers will enable industry, through management, work force skill, technological change and restructuring, to become competitive in appropriate areas and will make for a larger and more confident employer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to Senator Scott for 20 minutes or so, I wondered what reason the National Party had for introducing a matter of public importance. I cannot remember the National Party ever having done so before. It seems to me, having listened to Senator Scott, that there were two reasons for doing it. The first was to make sure that the Australian Labor Party did not raise a matter of public importance, exposing the sterility of the Government wages policy and the confusion and nebulous nature of its so- called pay freeze or pause, whatever it is. The second reason was to give Senator Scott the opportunity to present, on behalf of the National Party, an apologia for the National Party's failure to respond to pressure from its supporters to reduce protection-an attempt, in other words, to get the National Farmers Federation off Mr Anthony's back.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity that a matter which is extremely serious has been treated in such a cavalier fashion. The apparent global slide into rabid protectionism is a very serious question which carries, among other things, the grave danger that the world will be dragged further and further down into a depression as it was in the 1930s, as exporting industries in all countries contract because markets elsewhere have been closed to them. It is, of course, correct that Australia as a middle-sized trading power was not the crucial nation at last week's General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade meeting and is not the crucial nation in any global discussions on trade. We are, however, of some importance. It is a pity that such influence as we have had on the actions of other countries has been negative. They have been negative perhaps most importantly of all because of this Government's practice of and support for macro-economic policies, the effect of which is to stifle growth.

In only one of the seven years that this Government has been in office has it achieved real gross domestic product growth of 4 per cent which is about the minimum level required to maintain the existing level of unemployment. Not only has it practised growth stifling policies at home but also it has supported the insane economic policies of the Reagan Administration, the eccentric policies of the Reagan Administration, and the even more anti-growth policies of Mrs Thatcher in the United Kingdom. The effect of the growth stifling policies which this Government has both practised and supported is, of course, to develop an environment in which mutually destructive trade policies can flourish; and they do appear to be flourishing. The influence of this Government has been negative because, although it has behaved with piety abroad, at home its behaviour is marked by political chicanery and pork-barrelling protectionism.

We hear sanctimonious denunciations of the European Economic Community and the common agricultural policy for the dumping of agricultural products. Dumping, by definition, is the sale of a commodity on overseas markets at lower prices than the same commodity is sold at on domestic markets. Using that definition, Australia is dumping and habitually dumps eggs, canned fruit, dairy products, tobacco and wheat. There are no more enthusiastic advocates of those dumping policies than the members of the National Party who behave with such piety in the Senate and with such piety abroad. In all of those cases there are restrictive domestic marketing arrangements under which the domestic prices of those commodities are substantially higher than are the prices at which they are exported.

The influence of this Government has been negative because the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) has debased the quality of economic debate, as no previous Prime Minister has done, to the point where rational consideration of economic questions is almost impossible. He debased in particular the debate about protectionism with such pieces of newspeak as he employed during the Bass by- election in 1975 when he said that the unemployed textile workers of Bass knew about the dangers of big government. Of course, he was referring to the reduction in tariffs in 1974 which, compared with a couple of other factors that were operating at the time, had a quite minimal effect on the textile mills in Launceston or anywhere else. More importantly, of course, he equated a withdrawal, a toning down, a phasing down, of government intervention with big government, whereas the truth was the reverse. Because of that sort of continual debasement of economic debate it is very difficult to get sensible consideration of these issues. Nobody has made a greater contribution to the debasement of that debate than the Prime Minister.

Our influence has been negative because Australia breaches the GATT. I refer to the notorious Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd case in which Australia continued to sell skim milk powder in breach of its GATT obligations. Mr Sinclair, the responsible Minister at the time, said that he did not know about the matter. A Senate committee unanimously declared that it preferred to accept the evidence of Mr Webster that Mr Sinclair did know about it. We have breached the GATT in both of the last two Budgets in one quite small way. Nevertheless it was a clear cut breach. A provision in the GATT forbids the use of sales taxes in a way that discriminates against imports. There has long been a sales tax on imported wine, but in the last two Budgets that sales tax has been increased. This is another breach of the GATT. Australia's influence has been negative because the Prime Minister keeps telling different stories about this matter to different groups in Australia. Some of the time the stories he tells are not true. I will give one example. The latest issue of the National Farmer quotes the Prime Minister's response to this question: What is the Government going to do for the agricultural community and what response is the Government going to make to pressures from at least some sectors of the agricultural community to reduce protection for manufacturing industry?
The Prime Minister said:
The car plan that has been announced involves much greater imports coming in over each year of the plan and that will be a significantly increased share of the market.

That just is not true. In 1980 the import quota was set at 95,000; in 1981 at 88 ,000; in 1982 at 92,000; and the interim quota for 1983 announced last week is 81,000, the lowest of the four years. Apparently, the Prime Minister continues to believe and practise: 'Tell the mugs anything that will keep them quiet. Get them off our backs for the moment and never mind whether it is true or not'. The influence of this Government in this area has been negative because it does not have a trade policy. It has a sequence of stunts designed to divert attention from the wreckage of the Australian economy. The most spectacular of those stunts appeared in the Prime Minister's statement of 18 May of this year-the Fraser three-point plan for world recovery, the magic formula of messiah Mal to lift the world out of recession. There was to be a standstill in protection-the first point-and no introduction of new tariff or non-tariff measures. There was to be no increase in export incentives. There was to be a commitment to reduce significantly and progressively all forms of protection in accordance with a set formula to be determined through the mechanisms of GATT. That was what the Prime Minister said on 18 May. On 2 June the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) jumped on the band-wagon, boasted of the vital meeting of the Ministerial Council of GATT which was to be held in November and said that he would be taking the Prime Minister's major economic initiatives to that meeting in order to rescue the global economy. In a Press statement on 2 June he said:

I will be urging that the November meeting come to grips with the need to reduce protection of all kinds and to scale down the massive subsidy programs that are placing such a strain on taxpayers around the world and contributing to economic and social dislocation.

So we had the Prime Minister's original, much vaunted proposals to rescue the world economy and the Deputy Prime Minister saying that he would take them to the GATT Ministerial Council meeting in November, beating up the importance of the Ministerial Council meeting. But within six weeks the prime ministerial plan was torpedoed by the Government-indeed by the Prime Minister who, in a statement dated 19 July, said:

In concluding that no further general reductions in protection are practicable at this time, the Government was also conscious that the capacity of the community to accommodate the economic and social consequences . . .

That was the industry assistance package which repudiated the so-called plan-in fact the stunt-which the Prime Minister had pulled out of the hat less than two months before. He repudiated that and said that there would be no reductions in protection. Some people agree with that; other people disagree with it. That is not the point. The point is that this Prime Minister keeps saying different things because he does not have a policy; he does not have an overview, nor does his Government. All he can do and all his Government can do is to produce a series of politically motivated stunts. In the domestic economy the latest of those is the pay pause, freeze or whatever it is to be called. However, notwithstanding the torpedo of the prime ministerial policy by the Prime Minister on 19 July, Mr Anthony continued to big note himself as though the GATT Ministerial Council meeting had some real chance of success and as though there was a real possibility of the prime ministerial plan-already torpedoed by the Prime Minister-being adopted by other countries. The Department of Trade and Resources was more honest. In its annual report, tabled a couple of weeks ago, among other things with respect to this GATT ministerial conference it stated:
It is not expected that the Session will result in a major new round of trade negotiations.

Of course, a major new round of trade negotiations would have been mandatory had the Australian proposal been taken seriously. Notwithstanding that honest assessment of the situation from Minister Anthony's Department, he continued to act out the farce. At last week's meeting he intended to continue big noting himself but his plan was undermined because, rather than making pontifical and pompous statements to the Australian media, he was in fact harassed by phone calls from Australian journalists who wanted to know the details of the family home that he has in Canberra when he says that he in fact lives in Murwillumbah. He tells the Department of Administrative Services that he lives in Murwillumbah . He tells the Canberra Times that he lives in Canberra, in his family home. Of course, journalists are interested in the $85,000 profit he will make on the family home which he purchased with the aid of a 4 3/4 per cent government loan which he gave himself. They are interested equally in the 300 days travelling allowance which he picked up last year. So the plan rather misfired. Instead of being the elder statesman or a significant statesman in the world trade negotiations, Mr Anthony was harassed by Australian journalists who wanted to know the sordid details of the snout that he has been poking in various public troughs in recent years.

While Mr Anthony was busy abroad ostensibly canvassing for reductions in protection, Mr Peacock was busy at home doing the opposite. In that week he announced new motor vehicle import quotas, to which I have referred-the lowest of the four years in which the present plan has been in operation-changes in anti-dumping laws, the effect of which will be to increase protection, and an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into fatty acids and glycerine, because , as he put it, the industry is now facing strong competition from imports. Again, some people agree with those decisions; some people disagree with them. That is inevitable. But the Government has no consistent policy. Mr Anthony purports to be putting a powerful case for reduced protection and in the very week that he is doing that overseas, Mr Peacock is busy at home doing the opposite. That has been the unfortunate story of the Fraser Government through most of its life in most policy areas. What it actually does contradicts what it says.

The Acting Minister for Trade and Resources, Sir James Killen, put out a Press release-or at least, a Press release has appeared in the name of Sir James Killen. Frankly, it is so incoherent that I wonder whether Sir James has been paid back for some of the practical jokes that he is known to have played around Parliament House for many years. In other words, I wonder whether it is a hoax Press release that someone else wrote and on which he put the name of Sir James. I shall read a few extracts from it:
There is a pressing need to curb the rush to protectionism among major trading nations. Australia cannot ignore the consequences.

The Government frankly admits difficult economic problems face the world and this country. That is and remains one of the major considerations in the Government's calling of a Premiers' Conference for December 7.
Political interests are intelligible. National interests are paramount.
Every political party is under an obligation to acknowledge the existence of national interests. Beyond this, no country 'is an island entire unto itself'.

I am astounded. Some people might think that Sir James never had much contribution to make in policy areas, but he was fairly well recognised as a man with quite a good command of the English language. I wonder whether he put out that statement or whether he has been paid back for some of his own previous practical jokes.

This Government has no moral authority at home. It has no moral authority abroad. It deserves none in either place. The global descent into beggar-thy- neighbour protectionism has very substantial dangers not only in the economic sense but even ultimately, perhaps, in the physical sense. Australia has some real justification, however, for being somewhat more protectionist than a number of other countries because of the enormous deficit on current account which we piled up last year and which we look like repeating this year. We are running a deficit on current account of between $9 billion and $10 billion. We are in the same category as Mexico and Poland. Our current account has more in common with that of a banana republic than that of a fairly rich industrialised nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably about the same as that of socialist France.
—I do not know what it is in France. Ours is about 6 per cent of gross domestic product.
—I think that the French current account deficit is 9 per cent .

—Senator Rae says it is 9 per cent. Of course, on a global basis, the current account is in balance. It is necessarily so. Therefore, some countries are running very substantial surpluses on current accounts that offset the very substantial deficit we are running. That can be corrected in various ways. The present Government has corrected it by mortgaging our future, borrowing money overseas. It could be corrected by a massive devaluation or by some other mechanism which limits imports.
