SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Senate should be grateful to Senator Scott for giving us an opportunity to debate this quite serious subject. The seriousness of it has been reflected in prominent editorials in recent days. Yesterday the Melbourne Age suggested in its editorial:

SPEECH.PARA: The stubborn refusal of the EEC to agree to any proposals for trade liberalisation at the GATT conference in Geneva over the past week is an extraordinarily selfish and irresponsible stance. It risks igniting a bushfire in which new barriers to trade will roar through the world, as politicians from each country take action to protect their industries from import competition. And people in every country stand to lose from it.

The need for some action in Geneva to hold the line against protection was clear. The recession is affecting everyone. From all quarters, pressure is being applied to Governments to try to export unemployment to other countries by running up protective walls against imports, or by subsidising exports to dump surplus goods on world markets. We saw in the 1930s the ultimate end of these policies-low-cost producers are denied outlets for their production while high- cost producers are propped up by their consumers (or taxpayers). Everyone has to pay more to buy less, and economic recovery is delayed still further.

The virtue of the Fraser policy for a moratorium on new protectionist measures followed by gradual reduction of existing ones was that it recognised the reality that no country could afford to act alone in liberalising trade.

I believe that Mr Anthony was quite right in expressing his disappointment in the attitude displayed at Geneva. He is already concerned that Australia should be looking to other ways to offset the difficulties that will be presented as a result of conflict between the United States of America and the European Economic Community with respect to dumping heavily subsidised goods on the market. An article in the Adelaide Advertiser stated yesterday:

The collapse of the international trade conference in Geneva is a tragedy. The implications for the world economy are immense. Without firm international agreements on trade the greatest danger now is with the world economic growth already in neutral, if not reverse, an increasing decline in exports will plunge the world into a quickening downward spiral. This will increase pressures for individual countries to raise their trade barriers and this spiral could soon plunge the world into a protracted and chaotic depression.

As a result of the failure of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade meeting to address responsibly the issue of world protectionism, I think a number of options are open to Australia. The Australian Labor Party's answer, of course, is to advocate, as it has done for many years, increased protection in Australia .

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the Bowen line. The Hayden and Wran line is different from the Bowen line.

—It is a bit confusing. I will continue to suggest one of those advocacies anyway. The ALP believes that this will shore up inefficiency in industry and subsidise employment. I think this type of interventionist approach was recently adopted by the ALP spokesman on industry, Chris Hurford, who said that a Labor government would assist the ailing steel industry by taking over 50 per cent of Broken Hill Proprietory Co. Ltd. This sort of approach fails to recognise that the solution to problems facing industries such as the steel industry has nothing to do with government intervention but ultimately relates, as it always has related, to the supply and demand equation. This typical socialistic approach to the problem is not the real answer. That is abundantly clear and has already been recognised. I thought an article in the Adelaide Advertiser expressed the following views quite well:

SPEECH.PARA: But calls for greater protection against imports-to save jobs-are already being voiced loudly, by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, and the NSW Premier, . . . by manufacturers and by unions, but more protection for some industries will inevitably hit others, including the devastated agricultural sector. Greater protection will push up inflation, hitting the consumer even further. The Federal Government, which has so fervently preached free trade abroad, must resist the temptation to back-track at home. We must make ourselves more efficient, search out every market and pursue it vigorously. Only this way will Australia be able to progress on a solid foundation of efficiency once the recession is over.

That is why I drew attention at Question Time today to the need to stir up industry to take advantage of the finance that is available to research and development facilities. I thought it was quite incredible that less than 50 per cent of the money made available by the Government for industrial research in the private sector was taken advantage of in 1981-82. It seems to me that industry has to have regard for its own future welfare. It has to develop new technologies. We are quite capable of doing it. Attention was drawn to this matter in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on industrial research and development. Why is not more made of the public interest projects within the industrial research and development grants situation? The Committee pointed to some very significant areas into which industry should be moving rapidly to develop our technology. We mentioned in the report the production of liquid fuels from coal and other vegetable materials. We highlighted the example of Interscan and how it must be developed as an international market commodity. We pointed to export developments arising from military research. At present, Australia is doing a lot of very significant research in the Defence Research Centre in Adelaide on over the horizon radar, the Jindalee and the Barra sonar buoy. Research is proceeding with respect to laser technology for oceanography. Those sorts of things ought to be exploited to a far greater extent by Australian industry. I believe that we are failing in that regard. If we are to offset the failure of the GATT talks we have to do other things to secure Australia's position in the world. I noticed that the Age also stated:

For political reasons it will have to make some concessions. One only hopes that they will be concessions which add least to the costs of other Australian producers-especially farmers and downstream manufacturers-and can be most easily reversed once the crisis is past. If we seek relief from the recession in import quotas, we can forget about the recovery.

Therefore, any protectionism must be afforded in an extremely selective way and it also must be a very short term expedient. Pressures for indiscriminate protectionism must be resisted and more permanent solutions must be sought. The Australian Labor Party has no real answer to the economic problems that led up to the GATT meeting and the problems that have flowed from it. The ALP's socialist philosophy-or social democracy as it prefers to call it in an attempt to become a little more respectable in the eyes of the Australian community-has proved to be a failure overseas. I noted with interest Senator Lewis's question about the Mitterrand Government. Senator Peter Rae, by way of interjection a while ago, also asked about France. The philosophy of the French Government has led that country into great trouble. Since coming to office the French Government has taken certain actions that have exacerbated its own unique economic problems and those international problems, such as unemployment, that affect all countries. Over the last 12 months the unemployment rate in France has risen from 7.3 per cent to 9.1 per cent-nearly 25 per cent in a year. Over 400,000 people have been added to the unemployment pool in that country since the socialists came to power. Total unemployment now stands at 2 million people and recent estimates suggest that this figure will rise to 2.2 million this month. This is contrary to the promise made by that socialist administration a little over 18 months ago that it would keep unemployment below 2 million people . So much for the socialist approach to unemployment and inflation. Unemployment in France has risen despite massive government intervention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Austria.

—I do not know about Austria. I have not been there. I am not particularly concerned about Austria. In Australia the socialists' counterparts, the members of the ALP, are arguing against a wage freeze such as the one tried in France and given away a while back because that country was finding that the value of wages was being eroded. It had a prices and wages freeze and it gave up that proposition. I think our philosophy of having a wage freeze will certainly have an influence ultimately on the prices of consumer goods.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the answer for Australia will have to be to look to our immediate region. Although there are inherent problems associated with the development of another trade bloc, I think we are forced in this situation to look at our region in regard to the establishment of some sort of economic alliance. I recognise the dangers that Senator Scott described. We do not want to have a trade war. I believe that the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) suggested when he returned to Australia recently that we will have to look very seriously to our immediate region. Our region is not insignificant when measured in any terms. We should therefore ensure that our strength in this area is used effectively. If an economic alliance were established among such nations as the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, Japan, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and Australia it would represent over 440 million people living in countries whose gross domestic products totalled over $ 1,430 billion in 1981. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the Senate is indeed indebted to Senator Scott for raising this matter of public importance. The collapse of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is a matter of crucial concern to Australia. We must look to our laurels. We must immediately develop new trade policies. The aim of the Australian Democrats is to be even-handed to town and country. We are concerned to help our wealth producing industries, both primary and secondary. We believe it is possible to develop trade policies for Australia that will help our farmers and manufacturers. Their interests are not necessarily in conflict. The National Farmers Federation yesterday stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government must move positively to develop bilateral trade relations with countries in the Asian Pacific basin and the Middle East.

We agree with that proposition. GATT, being a multi-lateral trade agreement, has been very difficult for Australia. When it is all boiled down it probably has not helped Australia all that much. We must have a new multi-party strategy for world trade. We should mobilise industry-both primary and secondary-labour, government and the academic community to build a dynamic, unified and multi- party international trade strategy. International trade today is between countries and not between companies. We have tended to ignore the evidence in front of our noses which indicates that competition from overseas is very largely distorted in various ways by devices of government. Australia has very largely been playing by one set of rules for conducting world trade while all other countries have been playing by other sets of rules which they obviously find beneficial to their circumstances. Predatory trade practices designed to permit one country to gain an advantage at the expense of another constitute economic warfare. That has been going on for many years. Now, with the collapse of GATT, it has come out into the open. The real question is: How does the Australian Government get involved in a constructive fashion to evolve a new system that deals effectively with the competitive challenges that Australian primary and secondary industries face both at home and overseas?

To find workable solutions we need government involvement. We need the Government, academia and industry to work together to find an entirely new approach-new at least in our generation-to trade policies. While we are developing this multi-party consensus on a trade strategy there are undoubtedly certain emergency measures which we must take. I believe these emergency measures must be taken before Christmas. As I think Senator Lewis pointed out, our trade deficit on current account last year was $9,000m. It undoubtedly will be greater this year. Australia cannot continue along this path. We will become broke; we will become internationally insolvent very soon. One emergency measure which we must face immediately is the devaluation of the Australian dollar. We are living beyond our means. Devaluation of the Australian dollar would assist both manufacturers and farmers in the short term.

I believe the second emergency measure that we must face is to make it clear to the Australian public that we cannot have everything. Japan, during the oil crisis of the 1970s, was suddenly faced with an enormous increase in its bill for imported fuel. Because Japan knows what it can and cannot afford, it very quickly realised that it had to make some sacrifices and so it prohibited, amongst other things, the importation of beef until it got its economy back into balance. Australia cannot go on indefinitely importing whatever it feels like. We will go broke. There are many things that we must import. We must import farm machinery, telecommunications equipment and factory machinery. But it seems to me to be a matter of very simple common sense that at a time of emergency such as this we should not continue to import products that can be manufactured by our own industries. We have a critical unemployment problem and a critical balance of payments problem. Why should we import products which can be made in this country and which are already being made efficiently in this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —A sheer luxury.

—It is a sheer luxury that we can no longer afford, at least in the short term. We have to face import restrictions in the form of quotas on those products that can be manufactured in Australia. We do not suggest that a reduction in tariffs should take place. The Industries Assistance Commission has looked at our relative tariffs continuously. We are not suggesting that they be interfered with. But as an emergency matter quotas are unavoidable and we believe they must be applied immediately-that means before Christmas.

SPEECH.PARA: The third emergency action that I think is required is this: We have to start buying back the farm before we are unable to do so. We should seriously look at controls on the amount of money foreign corporations are allowed to borrow inside Australia. Such controls worked reasonably well from 1966 to 1972 and continue to work well in New Zealand. I believe we should change the guidelines on foreign contol which govern the operation of the Foreign Investment Review Board to require share control in Australian enterprises. We should allow, and indeed encourage, foreign portfolio investment, foreign loans and the transfer of foreign technology, but on our terms. To optimise the pool of investment capital inside Australia we should immediately terminate the arrangement whereby Australians can invest in foreign companies at will. We should also make attempts to stem the outflow of intra-company funds by a variety of transfer pricing policies. We should make the guidelines on foreign takeovers more strict . At present they are rightly treated as a joke by foreign companies. These emergency measures require the attention of the Government. Not all of them are long term solutions but they have to be put in place while we develop our new all-party, very largely bilateral trade strategy in co-operation with the Government and not in isolation from it.

Lastly I draw attention to what I think is a very ill-conceived propensity by the Australian Government to try to big time itself around the world. Australia is very small fry in international trading terms. The European Economic Community, the Americans and the Japanese really could not give a hoot about Australia. We might think they do but in actual fact Australia's total trade with the United States for instance represents 0.2 per cent or about one-fifth of one per cent of America's gross domestic product. Our trade with the EEC is about the same. Any comment along the lines that if Australia introduced quotas as an emergency measure that action would precipitate a trade war, particularly with countries such as those of the EEC together with the United States of America and Japan, is just so much tommy rot. Nevertheless, we do have to be concerned about our trading relationships particularly with those small countries of the South Pacific that require Australia's assistance. This particularly applies to New Zealand with whom we are developing closer economic relations. Of course, Australia is one of the few countries in the world that enjoy a favourable balance of trade with the Japanese. We would certainly not want to do anything that would put that happy situation at risk. I conclude by quoting from Keynes who said in 1930 that:

The voices which . . . tell us that the path of escape is to be found in strict economy and in refraining, whenever possible, from utilising the world's potential production, are the voices of fools and madmen.

What Keynes was saying then was that it is very important in a time of recession or depression not to have a contractionary monetary policy. The facts of the matter are that Australia, for the last three years, has had an amazingly tight monetary policy-a very contractionary policy. That is relevant to Australia's trade. It is relevant as far as our trading relationships with other countries are concerned. We have to utilise our own productive resources fully at home at the same time as we develop our trading relationships with other countries. In a word, Australia's tight monetary policy has to stop. It must stop quickly.

In summary, I am saying: Let us develop a new trading strategy in co-operation with government, academia, with our industries-both primary and secondary-and with labour. In the meantime let us adopt emergency measures which include a devaluation of the Australian dollar and quotas on most products which can be manufactured in Australia. Let us look to our bilateral relationships, country by country. By all means let us talk with the GATT countries but in the meantime let us develop bilateral relationships particularly with those countries of the South Pacific. Finally, our approach to economic management has, in the opinion of the Australian Democrats, been absolutely the wrong approach over the last three years. It is very obvious that we have had an increasingly contractionary approach to the amount of money in circulation in the economy. A reversal of this policy is required so that we can fully utilise our productive resources at home. Of course, the productive resource that really matters is our human resource.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the matter of public importance proposed for discussion by Senator Scott in these terms: The serious position for Australia and the world resulting from the failure of last week's GATT Ministers' meeting in Geneva. In some of the debate, this has been referred to as the collapse of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. I start my contribution on this subject by pointing out that GATT has far from collapsed. In fact, there were some positive results from the GATT meeting. I believe that one can be far more hopeful of results being produced than many of the newspapers and other commentators have been.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently when I was in Europe at both the Council of Europe and the European Parliament, I was told that the Economic Committee of the European Parliament expected it would not be possible to achieve results at the brief meeting but what it would seek to have were mechanisms established at the GATT meeting for the determination of a lot of these problems. It was said that if mechanisms were set up GATT would be most worth while. In fact those committees were set up at the recent GATT meeting. Whilst Australia did not achieve the sorts of dramatic breakthroughs and dramatic agreements which a lot of people would have liked to have seen-I do not think it is a matter where there is other than a relatively bipartisan policy in Australia and in many countries of the world-it would have been desirable to endeavour to get agreement on the spot at that time , to move towards the reduction of tariff barriers, particularly of non-tariff barriers to trade. It would have been highly desirable in Australia's interests if we could have moved towards a breakdown in the two matters in relation to agricultural trade which worry us so much.

One is the fact that we have been excluded from what was our biggest market in Europe in regard to virtually all our primary products. The second is that Europe as a result of policies which it calls the common agricultural policy for subsidising the production of primary products in Europe has moved from being a net importer to being one of the major exporters of a large number of primary products which we also export. The problem is, of course, that Europe sells these products on the world market at prices which are heavily subsidised. This is done to the degree where, to use an example, in 1980, beef which cost $4,000 a tonne or more in Europe to produce was being sold to Egypt for prices between $1,500 and $1,700 a tonne against Australia's competitive, efficient production price of about $2,200 a tonne. That is not fair trade. That is not a basis upon which it is possible to conduct trade in any world sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is dumping.

—Yes, it is clearly dumping. Europe has been engaging in a variety of dumping practices which I believe are starting to be recognised as such in Europe. There is very considerable hope that Europe will move away from that practice. We were given an assurance, for instance, that the new policy in relation to sugar will mean that in the next year there will be a 20 per cent drop in the production of sugar in Europe. That will make a marked difference in the amount of sugar dumped on world markets. Not so long ago Europe had what I think might be regarded as the total impertinence to dump a lot of sugar in Papua New Guinea, right on Queensland's doorstep where most of our sugar is produced. The sugar was dumped at ridiculous prices. I believe that decisions in the GATT agreement such as this are encouraging and that we should not over- react to such decisions by saying that they were not further towards what we would have liked. I quote from the GATT communique which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The CONTRACTING PARTIES have accordingly decided:
I quote one of the parts which states:
to ensure that GATT provides a continuing forum for negotiation and consultation . . .

A little later the communique states that in drawing up the work programmes for the committees established and the priorities for the 1980s the 'contracting parties undertake, individually and jointly' amongst other things:

to bring agriculture more fully into the multilateral trading system by improving the effectiveness of GATT rules, provisions and disciplines and through their common interpretation; to seek to improve terms of access to markets; and to bring export competition under greater discipline. To this end a major two-year work programme shall be undertaken.

That may have been putting off the evil day. I think it would be unreal to suggest at this stage that Europe has not recognised that it cannot go on producing subsidised surpluses and dumping them on the world market.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be costly to the ordinary European consumer.

—Yes. This is another point about which I found there was particular concern in a number of countries. One of the countries which very strongly voiced concern was Germany where people were saying: 'Why should the European taxpayer pay huge subsidies to produce surpluses which are then sold to countries such as Russia to help it because its economy is unable to produce enough to feed its people?' The concern has been heightened by the realisation that they are now approaching the full utilisation of the one per cent value added tax which is the tax revenue base for providing the subsidies. I believe it is quite clear that the Economic Community will not agree to increase that one per cent VAT. Therefore the position has been reached where the amount of subsidy being provided in Europe has gone as high as it is going to go.

SPEECH.PARA: In discussion with the European Commissioners-Senator Mulvihill was another member of the delegation and could confirm this-we received positive assurance that by April next year a new scheme of policies in relation to agricultural production will be in force and that the position will diminish the effect of subsidised products being dumped on world markets. I believe that we should not rush into a situation in which we have people screaming for protection to be added immediately and others screaming 'No, do not add protection', all as if GATT had been a total failure.

Certainly there are serious implications if GATT does not go on from that ministerial conference to use the committees which have been established, to use the negotiation and consultation processes to develop new policies. There will be a serious situation if a country such as Australia or any other country rushes out immediately to put up tariff barriers to protect itself. The war would then be on. That would be the disaster which, I believe, we need to avoid. It is not that GATT itself produced the disaster. What could produce a disaster is an over-reaction to the fact that GATT, in a few days of ministerial meeting, did not achieve as much as many of us would like to have seen. It is interesting to note what Paul Johnson, the noted English writer, historian and economist, said in an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Commission on 26 November. He said:

. . . if Australia adopts the right attitude to this and faces up to this and says 'We've got to be efficient or die', I think you can become efficient too, and you can compete successfully with your Asian neighbours. But I think to fall back on tariffs again would be a disastrous solution.

I was therefore a little concerned with the apparent emphasis which was put by the Australian Democrats on the reintroduction of further tariff barriers. I am not suggesting that we should remove all barriers and try to cure unilaterally the problems of the world. Obviously we would create massive problems and massive further unemployment in Australia by doing that. What we must do is positively not raise further barriers, positively encourage and assist in every way we can towards the negotiations which are going to follow. I was encouraged today to hear that the United States negotiator Bloch stated that whilst his reaction was one of disappointment he was going back to Europe next month for further negotiations and he does not believe that all is lost.

Australia is a trading nation. We will continue to provide employment in this country only if we can trade freely and find markets for our products. If we adopt policies which put barriers on free trade then we are not going to be able to engage in the trade which provides employment in Australia. Therefore I think it is a matter of some concern to find--

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot afford the imports at this level.

—We have to be able to afford what we buy and how we can afford it is by increasing our productivity, our efficiency and our exports. That is the point that Paul Johnson was making. We have to improve our efficiency; we have to be able to compete and we have to be able to afford then to be able to buy what we do not produce ourselves. I certainly agree that we need to have protection against dumping. The type of dumping, particularly of agricultural products, which has been going on so far as Europe is concerned is, I think, a public disgrace. We need to ensure that the protection stops that sort of dumping but we need to fall short of raising new barriers which impede the restoration of world trade which, I think everyone agrees, is going to come about in the relatively near future. I was interested to hear the Secretary- General of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Mr Emile van Lennep, say on 5 October:

SPEECH.PARA: We must face up to the fact that, especially over the last two years, there has been a serious deterioration in international trade relations. This has shown up less in the imposition of traditional trade restrictions-although these have been on the increase-than in the increasing use of less transparent techniques such as voluntary export restraints and the so-called 'monitoring' of imports, and, in particular, in the growth of domestic subsidies and other support measures to uncompetitive industries and companies.

I believe that he was pointing to a number of the reasons why Australia has got into trouble; why there are problems in the Australian economy. We have these problems because we have failed to do what, according to Paul Johnson, is now starting to happen in England. In answer to the question: 'Is the reason for that change the fact that there are 3.5 million people unemployed or is it a change that would be happening anyway?' Johnson said:

That is one reason, the heavy unemployment. I think the penny has dropped in the minds of many working people that high and unrealistic wage claims ultimately threatens their jobs. They have in fact seen jobs lost of their friends, possibly themselves because of excessive wage settlements. So what you might say is that in Britain the working people have been taken through, over the past 3 years, a kind of elementary crash course in economics and it is having its effect and is penetrating upwards through the unions, so that the whole business of wage negotiating is becoming more rational.

I believe that that is what we need to do in Australia. The wages pause, which is the Government's policy, is one of the important steps towards placing Australian industry in a position in which it can compete whereas raising further barriers can only have the reverse effect. Fifteen million people is such a small market-I think this is one of the points that Senator Siddons perhaps did not refer to adequately-that we need to be able to move towards having our industries producing things which can be exported overseas at competitive prices and be able to get into other countries in order for us to be able to restore full employment in this country. Increasing efficiency, the adoption of new technology, using the world economic recession as a pause opportunity to restructure some of the industries from the inside, to introduce and apply the latest technology to make Australian producers the most efficient producers are all the sorts of things which I believe can move us towards achieving that result, whilst at the same time continuing to do everything that we can to emphasise that GATT and its committees which have now been set up should develop new and better arrangements for reducing trade barriers in the world steadily and on a multilateral basis. I completely agree that Australia would be mad to try to approach the matter on some sort of unilateral basis. It cannot be done that way.

In conclusion I refer to the fact that the Council of Europe and the European Parliament have expressed concern about matters to do with trade protection which went a very long way in being similar to the concerns which we expressed but which were not reflected by what I regard as not a totally supported view by the European Commission when it argued at the GATT meeting against a lot of the steps which their own Parliament said ought to be taken. I think that too ought to be borne in mind when people are thinking about what the future holds in relation to the further steps that can be taken under GATT. As my time has expired I regret that I am not able to cover a couple of the other points that I wanted to make. I simply say that whilst the result of the GATT meeting could be serious it should not be described as a collapse and it should not be described as something where there was total failure. I think there is hope but it is going to be slower than many of us would have liked. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ANNUAL REPORTS OF COMMONWEALTH DEPARTMENTS AND AUTHORITIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement made by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) on Thursday, 11 November 1982, relating to the Government response to parliamentary committee reports on annual reports of Commonwealth departments and authorities.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 November, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was saying that the taxation Bills have created scapegoats for the collective abuse of the Australian public. Happily, this furore has died down in spite of the efforts of those honourable senators on the other side of the chamber to keep up public hysteria. They tried to maintain rage on this issue. Honourable senators opposite learned about this maintaining of rage in 1975 and they have never got over it. They have been maintaining their rage on that issue.
—It is certainly working with you. You have been abusing the Government for about a week.

—Senator Button is maintaining his rage. Perhaps Senator Button is trying to maintain my rage. That should have a very desirable effect. Indeed, it may well be achieved. The gallup poll in the Herald newspaper of a few weeks ago showed that people are listening to our arguments against retrospectivity. Quite clearly the majority of people-something like 65 per cent-are totally opposed to any kind of retrospective legislation. I draw a necessary distinction between punitive and beneficial retrospectivity. Some honourable senators on this side and some on the other side of the chamber have not. They thought it clever and sophisticated to try to equate the two-beneficial and punitive retrospectivity-suggesting that if one accepts benefits retrospectively one should accept punishment retrospectively.
—Absolute rubbish.
—That is the sort of argument which was uttered by people on the honourable senator's side and by people on this side.
—And Senator Missen.

—I am reminded by my friend, Senator Townley, that it was my absent colleague, Senator Missen, who used these arguments. I was severe on him yesterday and I made up my mind today that I would not be severe on him. We are speaking again and that is a good thing. In degree of foolishness, these ridiculous sophistries, these silly equations between beneficial and punitive retrospectivity, are just nonsense.
—But the Old Testament says an eye for an eye. That is what it is all about.
—Has Senator Mulvihill come back to us? For a while I thought I was going to enjoy peace in the third reading debate, but I see that Senator Mulvihill has come in deliberately to tempt me.
—You can handle bumpers.

—Yes, I think so. I can handle even slippery eels, but not whales . I have difficulty in handling whales. In any case, Senator Walsh again yesterday-I see he is here today-uttered a repetitious tirade. He always labels people as crooks, evaders and cheats and expects us to accept that just because he says it. As I said yesterday, if Senator Walsh will not make these remarks outside but makes these charges in what is, after all, a coward's castle that does not cut any ice with sensible people. If he will not make these charges outside no one will take any notice of his making them in the Parliament. Fundamentally, punitive retrospectivity outrages the principle of certainty before the law. That is why a number of us-I note that it is a growing number- are against this outrage of the principle of certainty. Indeed, the numbers are growing so much that if by some chance we could have a fourth and fifth reading in the Senate and if we were only allowed time to keep going I believe we would get the numbers.
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have heard the outrageous lies that have been said already in the Senate.
—I object to that. Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I demand a withdrawal. No lies have been stated by me in this chamber.
—He has made outrageous remarks about me.
—Senator Missen, I suggest that you withdraw that word.

—He has made outrageous distortions. I withdraw the word 'lies'. I know that is not a word we can use. I take the point of order that this honourable senator is filibustering outrageously in an endeavour to hold back this legislation and hold up the business of the Senate. I understand that in the third reading debate one is entitled to add some additional comments, but surely in the third reading debate it is not permissible to repeat again all the ridiculous rubbish, as the honourable senator has done and is doing again. Under the Standing Orders is there no limit upon tedious repetition which could stop this man from continuing to blast the air in this way?

—Order! There is no point of order. Under the Standing Orders an honourable senator is entitled to speak for 30 minutes. If the matter is relevant to a motion for the third reading of the Bill the honourable senator is in order.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy President. I am trying as much as I can not to be repetitious. I thank my learned colleague for the great tribute he has paid to civil liberty in this chamber! We often hear him talking outside this chamber about civil liberties but it seems that there is no civil liberty in this chamber. If one is opposed to Senator Missen one is not entitled to be heard. I record this for the future. On the matter of retrospectivity, the Americans are, and for 200 years have been, proud of the fact that they have a government of laws and not of men. That is to say, anyone who conforms to the law at the time is safe from the fluctuating wishes of those in power and even of the community as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Sometimes the law is technical, imperfect and deficient. But ultimately it is much more important to adhere to the rule of law than it is to start on the slippery slope of penalising retrospectively those now condemned by changing moral standards or even by hypocritical representations of what most people's expectations are in relation to tax. No one expounded the importance of being able to rely upon the law better than Sir Thomas More, although in his case also in the end the law was bent to conform to the strong political pressures of the times. Those honourable senators who are familiar with that magnificent play by Robert Bolt will know what the ultimate end of Sir Thomas More was. He was topped. There are a few other matters I want to mention. During the debate I heard some people say that this tax we are speaking about is not a new tax. I want to put right that matter. Section 55 of the Constitution states:
Laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of taxation, and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect.
In this case the second sentence is most important. It states:
Laws imposing taxation except laws imposing duties of customs or of excise, shall deal with one subject of taxation only . . .

The requirements of the second paragraph of section 55 which I have quoted have been met in that the Bill is a separate Bill from the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936 and the new tax liability arises in a Bill dealing with one subject of taxation only.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will get your preselection, don't worry.
—That is the basis of my statement that this is a new tax. It must be, constitutionally. If you read the explanatory memorandum, if it is not too difficult for you, Senator Button you would see--
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair.
—I was responding. I believe that this answers completely the foolish assertions of those people who have denied that it is a new tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally-I suspect some honourable senators will be glad to hear me say that-if this legislation is enacted in its present form it will work a great injustice on many of those to whom it will apply. It will make it easy in the future for retrospective legislation to be directed against unpopular groups or causes. To some extent it will deprive all Australians of that fundamental security that comes from knowing that the law depends upon general rules laid down in advance and applied by the courts. I hope that some of the lawyers in this chamber, who are so distinguished in chanting about civil liberty causes in other dimensions, are listening to my statement concerning what is wrong with this Bill.

The Bill treats those who are concerned with tax avoidance, whether they have done anything illegal or not, far more stringently, financially, than those who have been convicted of crimes of the gravest kind, such as drug trafficking. It also provides that the assets of promoters engaged in certain transactions, which at the time were legal, as well as those of their relatives will, irrespective of fault, be expropriated in 1982. Who can, any longer, feel secure in investing in, or carrying on an activity in, Australia that may be thought to be controversial? In such a situation there is no fundamental security for anybody. The fact is that others, members of the Australian Labor Party in particular, regard the Bill as setting a most important precedent in the field of retrospective law. Once the principle has been conceded in the face of indignation, moral fervour, change in judgment or new perceptions, it becomes much easier to concede it again and again. It is always possible to say that circumstances are very special. I suppose there is something unique about every situation that faces government. But what assurance will non-residents have if, for instance, overseas ownership of property in Australia becomes a highly charged and emotive issue? Legislation that would effectively strip them of their rights may be passed. What assurances against that have these people?

In conclusion, this Bill is an outrage against fundamental civil liberties. I would have expected that more people in this chamber than in the other chamber-I have listened for years to speeches by certain honourable senators on civil liberties-would have been on the side of the opponents to this Bill, which is an outrage against the traditional freedoms that we have enjoyed for generations and which will serve as a precedent for worse things to come. I commend all who feel as strongly as I do, and any others who may be converted by what we have had to say at the Committee stage, to join us in opposing this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the third reading, not because I feel that what I have to say will change anybody's vote but because I always live in hope that I will change someone's opinion. Most people would not have enough 'g-u-t-z' to change their vote; some are not allowed to do so. I oppose these measures at the third reading stage because I believe they are predicated upon wrong reasoning. They are predicated upon the assumptions firstly that they will bring fairness to the tax system and, secondly, that they will do away with what the Government senses as a rage outside against vendor- shareholders. I do not know whether there is a rage; maybe there is a resentment or something of the sort.
—It is expressed by 65 per cent.

—For the purpose of my argument I am prepared to use the term ' rage'. Where is this rage and what is it all about? I am prepared to admit that there is rage outside firstly because most people think that, taxes are too high . Politicians on both sides of the Parliament have been telling them that for 10 years-in spite of the fact that governments continue to spend money like water. Neither side of politics will get taxes down while both sides spend other people 's money on those who do not really need it. For as long as politicians are not prepared to create a proper needs-based welfare system we will continue to have high taxes. We ought to admit that and not go around making all these silly promises. Secondly, there is some rage on the part of the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer, who cannot split his income, when he sees that his neighbour can. This Bill will do nothing to remedy that.
—And who sees crooks getting away with it.

—There is rage about that, Senator Missen, especially on the part of those who live in Canberra-they are mainly the PAYE group-when they see that other taxpayers can split the family income between husband, wife and two or three children.
—They are not the only ones.
—No. Many people get cross about that.
—While crooks are getting away with it, too.

—I do not say that crooks are getting away with it. I wish Senator Missen would go outside the Parliament and name those crooks. It is very easy to make wild allegations. He is a great civil libertarian but he continues to make wild allegations. I repeat, there is a sense of rage on the part of the PAYE taxpayer, who cannot split his income, against the person, often his neighbour, who can do so and who pays far less tax on the same income as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: As against that, there is a rage amongst many of the self-employed against those PAYE taxpayers who work between 35 hours and 38 hours a week and get four weeks annual leave, 10 paid public holidays every year, a 17 1/2 per cent loading, maternity leave and long service leave. In contrast, the self-employed person risks all his assets and must work 60 hours a week to try to keep his business together. He feels a little cross about the amount of tax that he must pay. I put it to the Senate that the real rage in the community is not about vendor-shareholders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the gallup poll.

—I invite Senator Missen to run a gallup poll concerning the public sector superannuation rip-off, of which we are all a part. If honourable senators care to look at a list showing the standing of certain people in the community they will note that politicians rank below second-hand car dealers. If one were to add vendor-shareholders, politicians would probably rank below them also. If there is a sense of outrage in the community at the moment it is about public sector superannuation. It has been based on publicity about senior public servants and retired politicians who have walked away, quite lawfully-as did the vendor-shareholders-with $300,000, $400,000 or $500,000, 95 per cent of which is tax free. Yet what examples do Senator Missen and other people give? They speak of the businessman who sold his company for $100,000 and walked away with $47, 000 and say what a terrible man he is. Supposedly, this Bill is designed to remedy the rage in the community, which is said to be all about vendor- shareholders who, according to Senator Missen, have pinched $47,000. What about the rage against those in the public sector who are walking away with up to a half a million dollars in superannuation, virtually tax free?
—You would not take it away retrospectively, though, would you?

—Of course I would not. I think that would be totally wrong. Those who have had a benefit should not be deprived of it. I would be opposed to that. The next avenue of rage in the community, if Senator Missen really wants to know-we have been reading about it in the newspapers-concerns a couple of Ministers ripping off their travelling allowances. That is something that the public can understand. That is what the rage in the community is all about, not vendor-shareholders or wet Slutzkins, which the public do not understand.
—Read your gallup polls.

—The honourable senator is gallup poll mad. Strangely enough, he does not sense the rage outside about public sector rip-offs, be they by politicians or public servants. Funnily enough, I must know the wrong sort of people. That is where the rage is. That is why I am opposed to this Bill. It does nothing to remedy the unfairness in the tax system. We cannot continue to have in this country a system whereby some people can split their incomes and lower the incidence of taxation and others cannot. Everybody must be able to split income, or no one. We cannot have one sector of the community averaging incomes and using income equalisation deposits if that opportunity is not available to everybody. We cannot have special allowances for anybody in this community. If there are to be special benefits for anybody in this community they should be paid out through the Appropriation Bills. As long as we keep using the income tax system for appropriating money and shifting benefits and burdens between different members of the taxpaying community we will have an unfair tax system. This nit-picking away and picking up some vendor-shareholders will do nothing to bring about a fair, just and equitable tax system. That is why I am opposed to this bit-by-bit game law attitude that we are taking to tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude my remarks on the third reading debate with my third limerick, for what it is worth. It goes something like this:
There was once a government which sensed a rage
Which by retrospectivity it attempted to assuage.
But plans went wrong because the rage was so strong
About splitting super and TAs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to all of this debate with some unconcealed interest, I would like to take a minute or two of the Senate's time by filling in one or two points. This is one of the most important Bills ever to go through this Parliament. It is based on entirely new and erroneous premises for a Liberal government. The consequences of this legislation simply cannot be foreseen. However, they are potentially very damaging for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Three points have stood out through the debate. The first is a frank admission by the Government that the legislation is retrospective, in a punitive sense not in a beneficial sense. No argument has been advanced as to why the circumstances are so exceptional and so extenuating that we should support retrospectivity on this occasion. The second point is that no explanation has been made of why the Government or the Public Service did nothing. Both of them are to blame. It is not fair for the Ministry to blame the Public Service or for the Public Service to turn around and blame the Ministry. They are both culpable because under the existing legislation prosecutions could have been placed and the crooks- undeniably there are crooks in this scheme-could have been apprehended many years ago.

We seem to have developed a doctrine of the endless buck-not the financial buck but the one Harry S. Truman talked about that stopped at his desk. Unfortunately we do not seem to have anyone in this country, in either the Public Service or the Ministry, who has a desk that is big enough to carry a buck. People get paid high salaries here but no one seems to be prepared to take responsibility for his actions. In the four and a half years I have been in the Senate I have found it impossible to sheet home responsibility for any action for anything that anyone does in Australia. That is what is wrong with the country today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly the Government.
—You could not accept responsibility in a fit. If you listen to what I am saying you might learn.
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair.

—Yes, Mr Deputy President. Because no one is prepared to accept responsibility there is no leadership. We have this great amorphous mass of government and the Public Service, characterised by incompetence and inaction , is just sitting like a huge mushroom over the whole of Australian business and paralysing it.

SPEECH.PARA: The third thing that stands out in this debate is the rejection by the Government of any suggestion that innocent people will be trapped by this legislation. We believe that people are innocent until they are proved guilty. If there is any doubt we give the benefit of the doubt to the accused person. The belief that one innocent person might lose his life was one of the most potent arguments in the abolition of capital punishment. If that principle is good enough in the case of capital punishment-it is a principle that is embodied in the rest of our legislation-it should be observed in this case. We should not be legislating against a whole class just because the majority perhaps were guilty. Yet the Australian Labor Party and those Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia supporters on this side who support that legislation are condemning a whole group of people. It must be emphasised that those people, who are innocent, broke no law as the law stood at the time. The consequences and penalties that they are going to pay are very severe.

TALK.START.PARA: —They made a buck.

—No. If the honourable senator knew something about the commercial world he would know very well that a lot of them did not make a buck. The crooks did. The crooks have got out with a few hundred thousand dollars or a few million dollars and gone to the Channel Islands, the Mediterranean or Hong Kong, but a lot of people used the system legitimately to stay in business and to employ people. Some of those people probably voted for the honourable senator . This leads me to the appalling ignorance in the Labor Party and some, regrettably, on this side of the chamber. There is a total lack of comprehension of practical commercial life in Australia. It is no wonder we have a recession and that that recession is getting worse when such ignorance is displayed.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of this legislation will fall on three groups: It will fall on individuals and the business world generally and it will have a major influence on our overseas investment. I will deal first of all with individuals. Many individuals have been involved in family companies. If honourable senators know anything about family companies they will realise that in many cases all the members of family companies do not take an active role in running the company; one member of the family does and the rest of them have neither knowledge of nor control over what happens. Yet, everyone who is a shareholder in a family company is now going to suffer. The last six years have probably been the most difficult for generations in Australian business. The aim has not been, as Senator Tate might think, to make gross profits by availing themselves of whatever opportunities are provided under the Income Tax Assessment Act, but simply to stay alive and to stay in business tomorrow. A fight for survival, a fight to the death, has been going on for the last six years.

The effects of inflation alone pose enormous problems for business because, although there is an apparent increase in profitability, no real increase occurs . There is an increased tax liability which comes from increased gross sales. This position is not understood by the Government in any way at all, least of all by the Commissioner of Taxation or by the Department of the Treasury in giving advice to the Government. The true position of businesses has been deteriorating, as is borne out by the company profitability figures of the last few years. If profitability diminishes the opportunities for employment and the expansion of industry diminish and this poses severe problems for the whole of the Australian nation.

It has been imperative for many companies to use whatever means were open to them legally to stay afloat. I will give the Senate just one example of this. One man came up to me in Brisbane. This self-made businessman, who started from nothing about 20 years ago, freely admits that, after gaining the best of professional advice, he took advantage of a scheme that is now called the bottom -of-the-harbour scheme. He was not to know at the time that that scheme was involved. He said to me that he can now pay the tax if the Government proceeds with this legislation. He has the financial reserves to do it. However, currently he is owed $2m by other companies. He knows that the people who owe him that money have all been involved in these schemes. He knows that none of them can survive and that therefore he will go broke because he simply cannot afford $2m. Senator Button, with his simplistic little socialist mind, can laugh . However, this is a serious problem. Several hundred jobs are involved in this one case. This situation will be magnified a hundredfold in the Australian community. This is all unnecessary. Senator Button probably believes that all of these people have the money in brand new bank notes in 44-gallon drums. I am making the point that, apart from the crooks who got off to the Channel Islands- Senator Button, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) or anyone else will never catch the criminals because they have fled the country-the money was used by the rest of them to stay alive in a most difficult financial world.

The third thing I deal with is the effect on overseas trade and overseas investment in Australia. In Australia we have sheltered behind very high tariff walls for generations. That has allowed poor management in business and agreement to rapacious union demands with respect to wages. We have kept solvent by selling the farm and by having a high degree of capital inflow. One way or another we have sold off the farm and had an influx of money. What is happening today? Where have all those funds been going since this legislation has been talked about? They are not going into property development, they are not going into buying real estate, they are not going into the stock market, they are not going into starting companies which either have the potential to be profitable or are profitable today; that money is going into government bonds and fixed interest securities. It is going there because the overseas investor who formerly trusted Australia as a sure haven is now frightened off and he will only put money into government securities. In this respect we can look forward to a deteriorating level of foreign investment in Australia and that again has severe consequences for the Australian economy. The consequences for the future are tragic. In the simplest terms, we will lose jobs, we will have a higher level of unemployment. No one in this Parliament wants that.

Since the Australian Labor Party has been so vocal, I would like to muse for a moment on the consequences of this legislation and the way it will embolden the Labor Party to move retrospectively in other ways. There is no end and there is no limit to what the Australian Labor Party will now feel that it can do. Items that have been legitimate tax deductions for generations can be retrospectively ruled out of order and people can be made to pay. We can look forward to a capital gains tax being introduced. Most importantly, as members of the Labor Party are saying publicly, they can buy back the farm by introducing a retrospective resource rental tax. The way is now clear for the Labor Party to legislate retrospectively against the mining companies by imposing a resource rental tax which will send them bankrupt. A Labor government could socialise the mining companies at no cost to the Australian taxpayer except to the employment of our people.

As Senator Withers said, what is fair and reasonable and what is contrived and false is purely a matter of numbers in the House at the time. As Senator Martyr said, business must have certainty. As I said in my speech at the second reading stage, the financing of major company developments is now far too complex to be treated capriciously by the Parliament of this country. The problem that we are dealing with here is not the matter of bottom-of-the-harbour legislation; it is the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936 and its 1,092 pages. It has now gone beyond the level of reasonable comprehension. It is so complex that it inevitably must have many holes in it and there will always be dishonest people who will exploit it. Until we re-write that tax Act with the emphasis on simplicity we will always be faced with this problem.

I would like to conclude by telling a story. I have spent a lot of time working with aircraft and I have known many aircraft engineers. It is the sort of work that requires some patience, thought and precision. There is a saying that an experienced aircraft engineer uses in speaking to a novitiate who is impatient. That expression is: Don't use force; get a bigger hammer. That is what the Government has done in this case. Instead of thinking its way through what it was trying to do, it has just gone and got a bigger hammer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a contribution to the debate on the motion for the third reading of these Bills. I realise, of course, that the fate of these Bills is a fait accompli, that they will pass through this chamber. But they will not pass through this chamber with my support. I cannot support retrospective legislation. I cannot support the retrospective application of laws. I do not know to whom members of the Government have been talking, but in my travels I have not found anyone who is in favour of this kind of legislation. The Government will get these Bills through the Senate with the support of the Opposition. That is understandable because we have already been told by Senator Evans and Senator Walsh what the Australian Labor Party will do if-it is a big 'if'-it ever gets back into government.

SPEECH.PARA: By introducing this retrospective legislation the Government has opened the door for the Labor Party; it has opened Pandora's box. No one knows the direction the Labor Party will take if it ever gets back into government. That causes me grave concern. This retrospective legislation goes back to action taken in 1972. No one has been able to tell me yet that people who did not pay their taxes, who avoided their taxes or who used bottom-of-the-harbour schemes at that time did not break a law which was already in existence, that they did not offend against the tax laws then. If they offended against the tax laws then , why were not procedures put into effect to catch them at the time?

It is no good saying that this Government is responsible for what happened or that it acted irresponsibly. The Labor Government was irresponsible in this area because it was in government from 1972 to 1975. These schemes apparently were being used then because this retrospective legislation goes back to 1972. That indicates that both the Labor Government and this Government have been at fault because they did not catch up with the people who supposedly had broken the law. If those people had broken the law then that law must still exist unless, somewhere along the line and unbeknown to the Australian people, that law was repealed. If the law has not been repealed, if it is still there, why are we not using that law? Why do we need to pass these Bills now? The law is still there. The Government should use that law to force those people to pay the taxes that they have avoided paying. If that is not the case, if there was not a law at that time and if there is still not a law, the Government is now introducing a law to punish people retrospectively for doing something that was not illegal at the time they did it.

I accept the proposition that such acts were immoral, but if everybody were retrospectively charged with something immoral that he did in his youth or something he did 10 or 15 years ago we would be in a sorry mess. So far as I am concerned, this is retrospective law. It will punish people for doing something which at the time they believed, in all conscience, was not illegal. They did not believe it was illegal. That is the main point I bring up.

Some honourable senators on this side of the chamber, including me, tried to introduce into the Bill an amendment to protect people who engaged in these schemes in all innocence. The supporters of this legislation would not accept even that. What they are saying is that they do not care whether these people are guilty or innocent. They will bring them all in and catch the lot. That is what they are saying. They do not care whether people are innocent. I do care. I do not want to see people punished for something they did in all innocence. But no, they threw out that amendment; they rejected it. Only a handful of honourable senators on this side of the chamber had sufficient thought, compassion and understanding for the people who were involved in this matter in all innocence.

I think it is a time of shame for this chamber when honourable senators will not allow innocent people to be protected. What has happened to our so-called British justice? What has happened to the so-called laws of which we are supposed to be so proud? Firstly, the Government has introduced a law that will be retrospective. Secondly, it is not even prepared to allow some small measure of protection for those who were innocent, those who did not realise that they were breaking the law at the time they did something.

The point I now wish to make concerns the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia. We now have a Liberal-National Party Government. I have always felt proud of the fact that it was part of the Liberal Party's platform that it would not entertain the introduction of any kind of retrospective punitive law. That is what I understood to be the Liberal Party's platform. Yet I am now witnessing the passage of retrospective legislation. Again I point out that we are opening Pandora's box. I can imagine what would happen if the Labor Party were to get into government and Senator Walsh were to be sitting on this side of the chamber . I can imagine the type of retrospective legislation that he would seek to introduce. Senator Walsh and Senator Evans are already on record as saying that they will really show us what retrospective law is all about when the Labor Party gets back into government. All I can say to the people of Australia is that the Labor Party should never been given that kind of responsibility because it would use its power to bring in all sorts of retrospective law which certainly would not be in the interests of the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you against retrospectivity for land rights?

—We are talking about a retrospective law which is punitive, not beneficial. We are talking about punishing people retrospectively. That is what I will have no part of. Again I say that this legislation will certainly not pass through this chamber today with my support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most depressing features of this legislation, besides its implications, ramifications and implementation, has been the level of debate not only in the House of Representatives and the Senate but also in the public at large. We have heard many people, not just the Government, say often that this legislation is not about innocence or guilt. How many honourable senators have we heard interjecting today to say that people are crooks, cheats, robbers, thieves and possessors of stolen money? The rage and the indignation which have been kindled and fanned in the community, in my view, are not spontaneous and occurred not as a result of the revulsion over what people identify in a very clear, precise and articulate way as the stripping of companies, which they completely understand, but as a result of what we have seen in the media, in this Parliament and on two Australian Broadcasting Commission television programs. That has divided the community as it has never been divided before. There is no distinction between tax avoidance and tax evasion. There is no distinction between innocence and guilt.

SPEECH.PARA: A perception has been cast by some quite purposefully and knowingly that all the people we are talking about are crooks, cheats and possessors of enormous amounts of money that they have stolen, buried in the ground or put in 44-gallon drums, as was suggested by one of my colleagues. In fact thousands of small business people and thousands of vendor-shareholders in public companies may be affected by this legislation. I think the number has been assessed at about 10, 000. Of course, there are provisions that relieve some of those people, but by and large they can be affected.

Recently on my way to the airport I asked a taxi driver what he felt about this legislation. With expletives deleted, he said that he thought it was terrible that all these great tax cheats had stolen all this money. I said to him: 'What about the cash you pick up every day in your taxi?' He said: 'That is different. They are not after me. They are not after the little fellows. I earn this. This belongs to me. If I can rip off the Taxation Office, that is good sport; that is game; that is the national pastime of Australia. It is those big fellows they are after'. Of course, collectively we all recognise that something like $600m has been lost through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. But it has been variously assessed that between $10 billion and $13 billion in tax revenue is lost because of the cash economy. I do not hear the Australian Labor Party saying much about what it will do when it gets into office, if ever, about that kind of tax evasion as distinct from the tax avoidance to which the current legislation primarily refers. The regrettable thing about people such as taxi drivers is that, as a result of hysteria whipped up, they imagine that we are talking about a limited number of very wealthy people who knowingly and willingly contrived quite illegal schemes and arrangements to evade tax and that they are suffering as a result. I find that one of the most depressing features of this legislation .

I find it very regrettable that the Government, presumably not on the grounds of morality but on the grounds of the dollars and cents that it may not collect, cannot accept an innocence provision. Yet I notice that in regard to the taxation on discounted securities it is clearly said:

The view of the Commissioner of Taxation, which is reflected in the 1982 Return Form Instructions, has been that profits received on sale or redemption of securities purchased at a discount are assessable.
Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) goes on to observe:

The Government has decided that income tax will not be payable on profits received on sale or redemption of securities purchased at a discount before 30 June 1982, other than profits made by traders or dealers.
He goes on to say that the original assessment made by the Commissioner was quite valid and legal. But the Government has a different point of view. The Treasurer says:

The Government believes that this view held by the Commissioner is correct in law. However, representations put to me in the past few weeks have clearly demonstrated that a significant number of small investors had purchased discounted bonds in the bona fide belief that the profit on sale or redemption would not be regarded as assessable income.

Because of their mistaken belief, poor advice, bad advice, lack of advice or no advice they are now excluded from a provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act which would normally require a payment from them. Of course, one of the sad things about not having an innocence clause is that people will be hurt not only in a punitive, financial way but also in a personal way. There will be both vendor-shareholders and agents or promoters who are innocent. I do not think any reasonable man or woman takes the contrary view that some people are not innocent and will not suffer very badly. Some people will be bankrupted. As a result of being bankrupted they will be subject to all the sorts of things that prevail in the Bankruptcy Act 1966. For instance bankrupts cannot become a director of a company. They cannot continue to engage in their past activity. They must provide to the Registrar in Bankruptcy details of any change of address or employment. They shall not obtain credit or enter into business arrangements without disclosing to any person involved that they are an undischarged bankrupt. They must not leave the country without permission. They must provide full details of journey, flights, times, places and purposes of trip and must surrender their passports on return. Failure to comply with any of these conditions, of course, is a gaolable offence. I suppose that there might be those who suggest that that is not a penalty, that is not inflicting some kind of hardship. I think it is.

Finally, in my view one of the greatest casualties of this debate has been the respect and standing in which this Parliament has hitherto been held. In recent years I suspect that the respect and dignity with which people have associated this chamber and the institution of parliament have become fragile, to say the least. They are now in a delicate state of fragility. The conduct of a few individuals, motivated by their prejudices, hates, passions, obsessions and distortions of the truth, has reduced the standing of all members of parliament in the eyes of the public. If any good has come out of this debate it is that the public has now focused on parliamentary privilege. Perhaps before my time here there were isolated cases of people being defamed, damaged and, I suspect, destroyed, with many other pains being inflicted upon them. But I suspect that in recent times it has been like it has never been before. There have never before been the indiscriminate, imprecise and irresponsible attacks by political parties against certain members of the public that we have experienced recently. What adds to the magnitude of this diabolical action by some is that many of these individuals are quite incidental to the whole debate, the whole argument. They just happen to be political pawns in the pursuit of power by one party against another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say 'pawns' or 'prawns'?

—In your case, either will do. Names are being dropped like confetti. It matters not whether these individuals have committed an offence. Invariably the only qualification to be attacked is to be a financial member of the Liberal Party, to be associated in some vague and obscure way with the Liberal Party-
—And be a tax dodger.
—Would you like to qualify 'tax dodger' publicly outside ?
—Order! The honourable senator will address his remarks through the Chair.

—I was saying that a qualification to be attacked is to accept a position to serve in some way at a very modest salary or no salary at all on a government body. The worst sin is to have accepted an invitation by this Government to occupy a position on one of those bodies in the last seven years.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, taxation matters are complicated. They are sophisticated. There are very few people who can understand all the types of arrangements and schemes and even the sections of the Act. It has been demonstrated in the past that there is nothing so imprecise as a taxation Act. Yet we find now that, because of the emotional strain that is put into this argument, the community is more and more confused except in one area, that is, that everybody who will fall within the framework of this legislation will be a sinner of the worst kind-a tax evader and a cheat. The distinction between tax avoider and tax evader is now lost and I find that very regrettable. If any good has come out of this debate, it is that some people are being seen for what they are and the community has a better perception of the activities, the endeavours and the intentions of certain members of parliament. I very much regret that we do not have an innocence clause in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now into the sixth day of debate on this package of Bills and for the sixth day we have witnessed a most undignified and sordid intra-Liberal Party brawl on the matter. It is most distressing to see this once great party tearing itself to shreds day after day as it has been doing for the past fortnight. Even given that, surely the Parliament could have been spared the sordid spectacle of Liberal Party preselection speeches from most of the Western Australian Liberal senators. Those speeches were addressed to the Western Australian Liberal Party-not to the Parliament and not to the nation. They realise that they are in such a desperate situation in Western Australia, largely because of the heavy involvement in tax avoidance and tax evasion of prominent members of the Western Australian Liberal Party, that, if they cannot get No. 2 or No. 3 position on the Senate ticket in a double dissolution, their seats are not safe. Therefore, we have seen this unseemly scramble among most of them who are here to deliver their preselection speeches to the Western Australian Liberal Party under the pretext of a third reading speech on this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As an illustration of the depth of the division between that faction of the Liberal Party which supports unreservedly the tax evaders and that faction which supports them with a few reservations-that is the rest of the Liberal Party-a few minutes ago Senator Crichton-Browne denounced those people who had said that the vendor-shareholders of these companies had stolen money. Among the other people who have said that is the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). On 30 August this year, the Prime Minister said:
In a real sense the recipients of those funds have in their hands stolen funds whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth or stolen from other taxpayers it doesn't matter very much.

That was the Prime Minister. Frankly, I do not know how Senator Crichton-Browne- after the sanctimonious speeches we heard from him today, yesterday, the day before, last week and the week before that-can bear to remain in the same party as a Prime Minister who, three months ago, was describing the beneficiaries of these schemes, the vendor-shareholders, as recipients of stolen funds. Somehow or other Senator Crichton-Browne manages to make that internal reconciliation because I suppose that if another party were to be started in Western Australia- call it the non-Fraser Liberal Party or something like that-it would not be able to get one senator up. At least the Liberal Party, despite the bitterly feuding elements within it, will probably manage to have three or maybe even four senators up from Western Australia in a double dissolution. The three who have given their preselection speeches this afternoon want to make sure that they are among those first three.

Yesterday Senator Martyr treated us to a sanctimonious little sermon about civil liberties and civil libertarians.
