I think it is fair to say something about Senator Martyr's record as a civil libertarian. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Senator Martyr was secretary of the Democratic Labour Party in Western Australia. He was conscripting kids and sending them to the war in Vietnam. At the time, according to Senator Martyr and his party, all of those who opposed that war were friends of the communists and were traitors. He practised smearing of that kind, as secretary of the DLP, for many years. Now we are exposed to sanctimonious humbug in the Senate allegedly or ostensibly aimed against smearing.

In association with this charge of smearing we get the big lie that nobody has said anything about any of these tax evaders outside the Parliament. About a month ago, the Sydney Morning Herald had a front page heading: 'How Horgan avoided $7m in 5 years'. During June and July, I put out 12 Press releases and one as recently as last Sunday. I will read it. It stated:

The transcript of evidence given to the McCabe/Lafranchi inquiry shows that a belated addition to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Bill could save millions of dollars in tax for shareholders of Treamog Limited, a company substantially owned and controlled by Mr Denis Horgan.
Vendor shareholders' liability to tax will be determined by the actions of other people beyond their control, and of which they were supposed to have no knowledge.
That is the effect of Clause 3 (12) of the Bill now before the Senate. Significantly, that Clause was added almost a month after the original Bill was introduced.
The Clause exempts from tax people who sold a company 'pregnant with profits'-
That is a quotation from the Treasurer-

to a promoter, provided that the promoter then attempted to wipe out the profits with some kind of tax avoidance scheme which may have been subsequently disallowed in the courts! No tax will be paid on profits treated this way.
If the promoter did not attempt an avoidance scheme, the shareholders will have to pay the tax evaded.

Of the hundreds-possibly thousands-of companies purchased by Brian Maher, only a handful had their current year profits treated in a way necessary for exemption under Clause 3 (12). It just so happens that one of this handful of companies was Treamog Ltd, sold by Horgan to the Maher organisation on December 10th 1976 with current year profits of $3.7 million.

The fact that Treamog's current year profits were the subject of a tax avoidance scheme was revealed in the evidence of Lee Gabriel Hurley, the former Maher associate and Director, to Messrs McCabe and Lafranchi. An extract of this evidence is attached.

This is arbitrary and capricious law at its worst. It is utterly disgraceful that some vendor shareholders should pay while others will get off, just because they were lucky or cunning enough to sell to promoters who used tax avoidance schemes.

The Treasurer and the Government have refused to give any justification for the addition of Clause 3 (12). Indeed, the official Explanatory Memorandum even appears to contradict the Bill itself in relation to the Clause.
Since it makes sense in no other way, it must be assumed that the Clause was inserted at the behest of influential tax evaders who had the Government's ear.
It demonstrates more clearly than any previous scandal, the corruptability of the Fraser Government.
That is the end of the release.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you say that outside?
—Why don't you say that outside?
—I published that last Sunday. I am quoting from a Press release I issued last Sunday. Government senators cannot take it.
—Senator Withers has been bludging in here for five years.

—This is the only thing that has aroused his passion ever since the Prime Minister sacked him from the Ministry. Senator Crichton-Browne repeats the untrue assertion that nobody has said anything about these people or about him outside Parliament. He says that he is denounced inside the Parliament but is never denounced outside it. That is not so either because he is denounced outside the Parliament by, among others, members of the State Council of the Liberal Party, one of whom, Mr Bill Wreford, came to my office a few years ago and said: 'You are right about that Crichton-Browne. He is a crook and it is a disgrace that he is on the Liberal Party Senate ticket'.
—You won't say that outside the Parliament, will you? You dare not.

—Bill Wreford said it. A member of the State Council of the Liberal Party, came to my office and said: 'That Crichton-Browne is a crook. It is a disgrace that he is on the Liberal Party Senate ticket'.
—Why don't you say it outside the Parliament? You are using this place as a coward's castle, like you have done every day.

—I am not saying it; I am just repeating it. That is what was said by a member of the Western Australian Liberal Party State Council, a former President of one of its Federal divisions. That is what he said, and he said it outside the Parliament. He said it in my office.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I suspect that what Senator Walsh has impugned and directly said is almost a contravention of the Standing Order which protects senators' reputations in this place.

—I have been listening carefully, Senator, and I am of two minds on the matter. I have been watching it, and at this stage there is no point of order. I suggest, however, Senator Walsh, that you restrict your remarks to the third reading debate on the Bill.

—Yes, Mr Deputy President. Senator Martyr's objections to retrospectivity, like the objections of all members of the Liberal Party that I know of, are selective and not absolute. Mr Alan Hunt, for example, a former Minister in the one-time Liberal Government of Victoria, has said that in 21 years he was associated with 151 pieces of retrospective legislation.
—No wonder it is out of office.

—When it was passing all the retrospective legislation, it was winning the election. And there was no Liberal Party principle offended by retrospective legislation. Senator Martyr has been very upset by this legislation, which has some retrospective impact. But there was not a murmur from him about the 22 pieces of retrospective legislation passed by the Court Government between 1974 and 1981. He was good enough to tell us yesterday that he was outraged by another piece of retrospective legislation which affected a former employer of his.
—What evidence have you got for that?
—Senator Martyr used to write for the Independent. He used to write under his own name.
—When? Give us a date and time.
—Order! I suggest, Senator Walsh, that you restrict your remarks to the third reading of the Bill before the chamber.

—With respect, Mr Deputy President, this is relevant, because Senator Martyr was complaining again about retrospectivity. His objection to retrospectivity is selective and not absolute, as are the objections of all Western Australian Liberal Party senators, as the public record clearly shows, because none of them objected to any of those 22 pieces of retrospective legislation passed by the Court Government, some of which had punitive effects. They have had the opportunity, in the Committee stage and in the third reading debate, to draw attention to any objections they may have, and they have not taken it. The plain fact is that what is objected to is not retrospectivity per se but the effects that particular pieces of legislation have on people.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been abundantly clear in this debate, and in all previous debates on these Bills, that there are certain people in the Liberal Party who have a very permissive attitude to tax avoidance and tax evasion. Not surprisingly, many of them come from Western Australia. I say 'not surprisingly' because documents tabled here and presented elsewhere have shown that at least five members of the Western Australian Liberal Party's Finance Committee sold companies to the Maher organisation, and that one member of that Committee was a major promoter of these schemes in his own right. Indeed, a meeting of the Western Australian Liberal Party Finance Committee must have been a bit like a meeting of the Brian Maher board. A former Minister in this Parliament, the former member for Curtin, was a shareholder in Automotive Holdings, a public company which sold off at least 13 subsidiaries to the Maher organisation. Whether or when that Minister declared his shareholding in that company to the Prime Minister is a matter which the Prime Minister has, as yet, declined to tell us. But given that sort of background in the Western Australian Liberal Party, it is not surprising that the Western Australian Liberal senators, and members of the House of Representatives, have taken a more permissive attitude towards tax avoidance and tax evasion than the Prime Minister. Likewise, Senator Bjelke-Petersen--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I cannot say that I get terribly offended by anything that Senator Walsh says, because it is hard to distinguish that from anything that is decent. However, in the last minute he has impugned the motives of those Western Australian Liberal Party senators who have supported an innocence clause and opposed this legislation.

—I do not think that there is any point of order arising from the remarks made by Senator Walsh at this stage. However, I would ask Senator Walsh to keep his remarks confined to the third reading debate.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I do not believe that I impugned the motives. I can do so if anyone would like me to do so. It would not be difficult.
—Senator Walsh, I have ruled that there is no point of order. Proceed with the debate.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I was drawing attention to a matter revealed in this debate and in the previous debates. That is that the Western Australian Liberal members of this Parliament have a more permissive attitude to tax avoidance and tax evasion than the Prime Minister, who is hardly hard-line on the subject-at least, not these days-and that is related to the attitudes of the branch of the Liberal Party that they represent. Senator Withers made some very valid points about the Income Tax Assessment Act and the broader question of taxation. I believe that one task which is badly needed is a complete re-writing, simplification and shortening of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I sincerely trust that at some time during its first term of office the next Labor government will do that. Senator MacGibbon raised the extraordinary argument that it was not right to retrieve the money from people who should have paid it in tax years ago if they had invested that money in employment generating activity.
—Good; I will rob a bank and start a business.

—Exactly. The logical extension of that argument is that it is all right to rob a bank as long as one uses the proceeds to establish an employment creating activity. I find that quite extraordinary. Senator MacGibbon's suggestion that at some time in the future a Labor Government would cancel explicit deductions from taxable income written into the Income Tax Assessmet Act is pure nonsense.
—I think that Senator MacGibbon's speech is worthy of more comment than that.

—Perhaps Senator Chipp might like to add to what I have said. I have made only that one note about it. This legislation was weak when it was introduced. It was watered down by the Government. But it should still be passed , and it will be passed because it is better than nothing, albeit only just. It ought to be noted for the record that it will be passed only because it is supported by the Australian Labor Party. Had it been left to the Liberal Party and the National Party, all of the recipients of stolen funds, as the Prime Minister called them only three months ago, would have been able to keep all the money forever, whereas now, because of the support of the Labor Party, some of them will have to pay some of it back. There is no penalty imposed by this legislation; that is another false assertion, repeated ad nauseam. Some people will be required to pay, as taxation, some of the tax that they should have paid anything up to 10 years ago. Even that minority who will have to repay some of what they should have paid years ago is getting out of it very lightly because they have had the use of money, free of interest, for periods of up to 10 years and when they finally pay they pay in inflation eroded dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of guilt or innocence, which really boils down to a question of knowledge as to what the promoters were going to do with it, does not arise, because they will not be punished. All that they will have to do is pay what should have been paid long before. Questions of guilt or innocence are not relevant to this legislation-any more than is the guilt or innocence of an age pensioner who is overpaid because of an error in the Department of Social Security, not because he has submitted any fraudulent claims but because of an error made by someone in the Department and the pensioner must pay the money back. If there are innocent vendor-shareholders they innocently received the money and many years later they will innocently pay some of it back-or at least some of them will. It is not correct, as is asserted by various members of the Liberal Party rump or mainstream-I am not sure which, but it wants to allow all the tax dodgers to keep all the money for ever-that there is no distinction between the innocent and the guilty. That is untrue. Brian Maher, for example, and a number of other promoters have already been charged with criminal offences . The vendor-shareholders will not be charged with any criminal offences. Some of them will have to repay some of the money that ought to have been paid in tax long ago.

Finally, I hope that at some future time Senator Sir John Carrick will not have the audacity to come into the Senate and accuse the Labor Party of obstructing Government business. As I said in the beginning, it is now the sixth day of debate on this matter. Most of the time has been occupied by the rump or mainstream-whichever it is-of the Liberal Party which is opposing its own Government's legislation and denouncing its own Prime Minister. Members on the Government side have occupied a great deal of time in debate, for whatever reason, whether it is to deliver an early pre-selection speech for the State Council of the Liberal Party in Perth, or whether they think they can further wear down this weak Government and extract some further concessions or for whatever reason, the fact is that the time has been taken up by them. The legislation, weak and watered down though it is, will now be passed. It is better than nothing, but only just.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill will formally impose recoupment tax on former owners of companies stripped of pre-tax profits and does so on the basis of the rules contained in the assessment Bill I have just introduced.

As I have explained, liability for the vendors recoupment tax will fall initially on the persons who sold their shares, but where it is impracticable or inappropriate to levy the tax at that primary level it will be possible to trace through to more remote links in the ownership chain and levy the tax at levels below the primary level.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT ASSISTANCE (LOANS GUARANTEE AND SUBSIDY) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that this matter was to be dealt with in conjunction with the report of the Senate Standing Committtee on Education and the Arts. That being so, before we move to the Committee stage I shall make one or two comments about that report. The Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill was debated in September. The Bill was referred to a Senate committee with specific terms of reference because the Bill was not very clear in its effects in a number of ways, and its lack of clarity was reflected by the report of the Senate Committee. I congratulate the Committee on the concise and clear report which it brought down because now the Senate can be satisfied about a number of matters which were of concern when the Bill was last before the Senate. I refer particularly to certain paragraphs of the report which contain the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of those recommendations relates to the agreement with the banks and the suggestion made by the Committee that that should be renegotiated in time. Recommendations 5, 6 and 7 contain a suggestion, which is very important as far as the Opposition is concerned; namely, that the operation of this proposed student loans scheme be reviewed by the Department of Education on a regular basis and, more particularly, by the Senate Standing Committee. In paragraph 9 of the recommendations of the Committee it is suggested that the Committee should review the scheme in March 1984. I think all those matters are important considerations in determining the viability of the loans scheme. I think they should be taken into account, particularly by the Minister for Education ( Senator Peter Baume), if I might say so. I say that not in any adversary sense; I think it is most important that, if the best value is to be obtained from this scheme, it is subject to constant review. I wish only to indicate that in speaking to the second reading motion I stated the attitude of the Opposition to this legislation as a whole. I shall simply reiterate the points I made. In our view the legislation does not grapple with the real issues in the sense that it does little to increase access to post-secondary education and tends to favour students of more wealthy backgrounds who would be more likely to take out loans.

In the second reading debate we also indicated that we should perhaps give further attention to existing loans schemes at tertiary institutions, particularly universities. I note that the Senate Committee has recommended that further money be made available to those existing schemes in the hope that they will be improved, with the implicit suggestion that they are of more benefit to students than the proposed scheme now before us. However, as I said, the Opposition does not oppose the legislation. We believe it will provide some benefit to some students. To that extent it is supported. We would like the Minister, perhaps at the Committee stage, to make some comment on the Senate Committee's suggestions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support for the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill. We were pleased with the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. I am grateful for the comments just made by Senator Button on behalf of the Opposition. The Government will be keeping the Bill under review and will be learning from experience of any problems that arise. We believe the Senate Committee did an excellent job, especially having regard to the short time available to it. I am grateful for what has been said by the Opposition and for the support which is to be forthcoming for this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 3, sub-clause (3), leave out the sub-clause.
Clause 3 sub-clause (3) reads:
For the purposes of this Act, a person is not an eligible student if he is included in a prescribed class of persons.

I think the scope of such a sub-clause unfortunately leaves open a doubt as to how this sub-clause could be used. Fairly obviously, there could be some classes of people one may wish to eliminate. If that is the case I believe those people ought to be included in a Schedule in the Bill. In other words, if it is desired by the Government to eliminate a class of persons who are for example, in prison -though why that would necessarily be the case, I do not know; but let us take it that that may be one of the classes the Government wishes to proceed against- that class of persons could be set out by means of a schedule. It is sloppy work on the part of the advisers of the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) not to be able to delineate and name these classes of persons.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 4, clause 7, at end of clause, add the following sub-clauses:

'(2) Money payable to the Commonwealth under sub-section (1) shall be paid in a manner prescribed by way of a surcharge upon any income tax payable in accordance with the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 by the person liable to pay that money.

'(3) A liability under sub-section (1) shall be deemed to have been discharged at the expiration of 5 years after the payment to the Commonwealth in accordance with sub-section (2) of any money for the purpose of the discharge of that liability.'.

I have moved this amendment because it seems to me that it will be far more equitable to repay money borrowed under a loans scheme by way of a surcharge upon tax. One of the matters raised in this debate has been the psychological effects that loans may have on a range of people in our community. My amendment seeks to avoid most of the problems. For example, under my amendment a person who enters into a loan and upon graduation is not employed and therefore is not paying tax would not be required to repay that loan in any shape of form. If, on the other hand, a person upon graduation goes straight into a reasonable medical practice he would be required to repay the loan within a short period. I have suggested in the second part of my amendment that after five years there ought to be a cessation of the obligation to repay the loan.

I believe that we should look at the family aspect. We know from statistics that a large number of people who graduate from universities do not take up any paid employment. For example, many women graduates choose to have a family rather than take up a profession for which they may have been trained. It could be that one or other of the spouses may not wish to work. It could also be that a married couple have to look after an elderly relative and that the husband, for example, may stay at home to undertake that social duty. One can range far and wide. However, I believe we ought to make it fairly clear that after five years a person in employment would have repaid the money and that a person who had not been in employment would not have to repay the loan. The liability would not be hanging over his head. For example, a couple who were married when they were at university could have a double debt. A relatively short time after they leave university they can apply for a home loan. If they have a debt of $16,000 hanging around their necks they will not be eligible for one.

If my amendment is passed we can say: 'If you have been employed you will have paid off the loan. If you have not been employed you will not have paid off the loan. But, no matter what the situation is at the end of five years, you can at least return to your normal existance and have the normal expectation of being able to buy a home and engage in other types of activities.' I believe that this would be a far more sensible means of proceeding in terms of repayments. I believe ultimately it would avoid a whole range of problems. My amendment would allow the Government to implement its loan scheme but, on the other hand, it would provide an equitable, fair and just means of repayment.

—I must say to Senator Button that before we came into the Parliament with this criticism we took advice from the law officers and from Parliamentary Counsel. That is the advice we were given. We have a subsidised rate of interest . We have maximum rates of repayment per month. There is a maximum percentage of a person's income which can be called upon by way of repayment. In view of those factors, we have gone some way to try to make sure that the repayment provisions are not onerous. SPEECH.PARA: Neither am I critical of the methods of repayment that the Minister raised by way of objection to the point I was making. I am raising a point with respect to repayment to try to avoid those psychologically damaging problems which the research and the evidence in relation to such loan schemes around the world has shown up and which were referred to in the second reading debate. That just happens to be the case. We may not like it but we know that it is the case that people from low income families are deterred by those types of considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

I undertook to try to answer some of the points raised by Senator Macklin and Senator Button. When people take out a student loan they will, of course, be undertaking an obligation. I would expect that they would undertake the loan with the expectation of repaying it and of discharging that obligation. SPEECH.PARA: The provisions which we provide-I remind honourable senators of them-give a preferential discounted interest rate to apply to the loans, give a holiday before repayment is due and impose a limit on income. TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but you were a distinguished doctor making that request. How would they have gone if they had done that themselves?
—I am very grateful for Senator Chipp's kind words. The first time I did it I was a very junior doctor.
—But you were a doctor; you were a somebody.

—I understand Senator Chipp's point. People must be able to enter the system. But the point we are making is that we are sure the banks will be willing to renegotiate. I come back to the amendment which suggests a use of the tax mechanism and which has at least a presumption within it that a person's declared taxable income in fact reflects something about his capacity to pay. I will not outline the briefing material that I have here which suggests that there may be at least some difficulties in making that assumption too easily.

Assuming that the context is as the Minister has outlined-for example, that a person finds himself chronically unemployed, which is quite a possibility, or that the person has been married and he or she is not the breadwinner in the family- perhaps we may make the move on from the banks' position to what the Government' s position would be in relation to that. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

We had put to us by a number of our witnesses the need for extensive financial counselling for students who are having financial problems. DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might suit the convenience of the Senate to have a cognate debate on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill with separate questions being put on the second reading and separate consideration in the Committee stage.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate covering these Bills? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating cognately the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and the States Grants ( Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. These Bills appropriate Federal financial assistance for schools and tertiary institutions for 1983. The Opposition does not oppose these Bills but will be moving amendments to the motion for the second reading of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill and at the Committee stage to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. We have some concern about the funding policies that are to be implemented through the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill. The Fraser Government's funding policies for schools have consisted mainly of directing money away from government schools and needy non-government schools towards the wealthier non-government schools resulting in the proliferation of new private schools, which is a matter of particular concern on which I will be making some comments later in this debate. This redistribution upwards in a socio-economic scale that we see in the Bills before us is, of course, in line with the overall economic and political strategies of this Government, which have been to direct public money away from areas of need towards areas of privilege. Just last week in the Senate, on behalf of the Opposition, I tabled a number of documents that demonstrated that since 1976 the effect of the Fraser Government's funding policies was an increase in Commonwealth general recurrent grants to non- government schools. Of course, within that increase in grants to non-government schools the largest increases have gone to the wealthiest non-government schools . As has been demonstrated in this Senate very recently, government schools have suffered a decline in real funding.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has continued the Fraser Government's strategy of treating government schools and non-government schools differently and, of course, the difference has been to the disadvantage of the government school sector. As the Senate will be very well aware at this stage, the Government has dropped the cost supplementation process through which, until this year, schools were compensated for unavoidable cost increases at the end of the year. However, this year the Government attempted to predict the cost increases for the year and to incorporate an allowance within grants to provide for those increases. As predicted by the Australian Labor Party, that allowance was inadequate. However, in compensating schools for the funding that was lost the Government has said to the non-government school sector that it will provide full compensation for cost increases which were experienced during the grant period. On the other hand, in relation to government schools, the Government will only partially compensate for cost increases. The upshot of this decision is that state schools are being asked to absorb some of the cost increases.

The Federal Government, while maintaining the real value of grants for non- government schools, is allowing its support for government schools to slip further. Half way through this year the Government announced an increase of $6. 3m in grants for the government school system. However, the Government did not announce that at the same time the government school system was losing $5m because of the Government's failure fully to compensate government schools for cost increases. Honourable senators will be aware that most cost increases in schools relate to salary increases, which account for approximately 80 per cent of total expenditure. Other unavoidable costs include increased charges for maintenance and electricity. These kinds of cost increases cannot be absorbed without a reduction in courses or facilities; in other words, without a reduction in the quality of education. The Australian Labor Party believes that all schools-government and non-government-ought to be fully compensated for cost increases which inevitably will take place during any funding period. We believe it is highly discriminatory to maintain the value of grants to non-government schools while asking government schools to reduce their operations. Government schools have been forced to absorb around one-third of cost increases during the latest grant period and this is having a serious effect on the quality of education in those schools.

A comparison of the different income levels of government schools and non- government schools demonstrates the very different levels of resources available to children in different categories of schools. During last week's education debate in this place some very illuminating tables were presented to the Senate by Senator Button. I refer honourable senators to the tables which appear on pages 2728 and 2729 of last Wednesday's Senate Hansard. They show that in 1982 the standard cost per pupil in a government primary school was $1,480 per annum. The comparable expenditure on a pupil in a wealthy non-government school was $2, 392 per annum, or 162 per cent of the expenditure on the government school pupil . However, in a needy non-government primary school the average expenditure per pupil was only $1,290 per annum; that is, only 70 per cent of the average expenditure per pupil in government primary schools. Comparable figures for secondary schools are $2,402 per annum per pupil in government secondary schools and $3,889 per annum per pupil in a wealthy non-government secondary school. This figure is 162 per cent of the per pupil expenditure for a government school . The figure is $1,729 per annum per pupil for a needy non-government school; that is, only 72 per cent of the per pupil expenditure for a government school.

I must state again to honourable senators that the Labor Party supports the principle of equal educational opportunity for all Australian children. Huge percentage increases in Commonwealth grants to wealthy non-government schools, which already spend more than twice the amount per pupil spent by the poorest non-government school and 62 per cent per pupil more than government schools spend, is simply not an equitable deal for the majority of Australian children in either government or non-government schools. I remind honourable senators that about 80 per cent of all non-government schools operate on low resources. Of course, many of these schools do not have much chance of raising the level of their resources because they serve poor communities. In the view of the Federal Opposition they are the schools which should have funding priority.

The effectiveness of the Australian Schools Commission has been continually eroded over the seven years of office of the Fraser Government. The Schools Commission was set up by the Whitlam Government to provide an objective national survey of the needs of Australian schools and to make objective professional recommendations to the Government on the funding needs of these schools. It was from the work of the Australian Schools Commission in its early years that the Whitlam Government's program of school funding-funding which was entirely equitable and which was based on the needs of the schools and the students in the schools-was derived. However, in successive Budgets over successive years the Fraser Government has limited the objectivity of the advice the Schools Commission has been able to give. The Government has imposed guidelines on the Australian Schools Commission and, as a result, it has been increasingly difficult for the Schools Commission to make an objective assessment of the needs of schools, be they government or non-government. I think this erosion of the professional advice able to be given by the Schools Commission has been very much to the detriment of education in Australia.

Another matter of great concern not only to the Federal Opposition but also to the community generally is the effect of the Government's schools funding policies in encouraging the establishment of new private schools. In many cases- I must qualify that by saying not in all cases-these policies have led to a very serious waste of public resources. The problem was canvassed by the Schools Commission in its report for the 1982-84 triennium. The Schools Commission raised concern at the likely underutilisation of government schools at a time when new private schools were springing up like mushrooms. Very real concerns are being expressed throughout the educational community and, indeed, in the media, about the educational value of many of the new schools which have sprung up under this system. Only today in the media there has been quite extensive coverage of a report which has just been brought down by the Schools Commission concerning these new private schools. I draw the attention of honourable senators to that. A report appearing in the Age today stated:
More than 130 new private schools opened in Australia in the past three years and immediately became eligible for Federal Government financing . . .
The gazette lists all private schools which qualify-

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to be registered by the State.

—Senator Baume interjects at this stage that the schools have to be registered by the State. I want to make a comment on that. It is the case that any school that is able to receive Commonwealth funding has to be registered by the State but I want to place on record the very grave concerns the Opposition has about that registration process. I draw to the attention of Senator Peter Baume the proliferation of such schools as those of the Hare Krishna movement, which believes in the superiority of the male gender over the female, also the vast number of schools which come under the Accelerated Christian Education Group, a kind of fundamentalist American Christian sect which is establishing schools throughout this country.

SPEECH.PARA: A report in the Sydney Morning Herald, which doubtless Senator Peter Baume has already seen, draws attention to this fact. The article points to the existence of such schools as the Wahroonga Christian Academy and the Sherwood Hills Christian School, which it says take their curricula from an American fundamentalist group called Accelerated Christian Education. The article states:
Accelerated Christian Education is part of the right-wing United States Moral Majority group. Its leader, Dr Jerry Falwell, was co-sponsored by ACE on his tour of Australia this year.

Senator Peter Baume might find it quite acceptable that some bizarre cult in the United States of America can move its organisers to Australia and go about the countryside establishing schools; moreover, that those schools should be able to obtain registration from State and territorial authorities and immediately become a drain on public funds. The Minister might find that quite acceptable but I can assure him that the proliferation of such schools, pandering as they do to certain sects which have been imported, is a matter of concern to the Federal Opposition and, I believe, to anyone who takes education seriously. Perhaps Senator Peter Baume would like to take the ultimate libertarian position that anyone should be able to set up a school for any purpose and receive Commonwealth funds. Perhaps he believes that the nazi movement in Australia ought to be able to establish its schools; that neo-fascist organisations throughout the country should similarly be able to establish them and receive Commonwealth funds to assist in running them. If he adopts that position I can assure him that his view is not shared by the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you impose a moral or religious test? You are really being very foolish.

—The honourable senator does raise what I admit is the vexed question of making value judgments as to which schools we, as a society, believe ought to be funded and which we believe ought not to be entitled to receive Government funds.
—You have made it pretty clear what your views are.
—Yes. I should make it quite clear that I am very concerned about the funding of schools which promote a certain American cult in this country.
—Last week you acknowledged a political right to choose a certain kind of education.

—Senator Martyr demonstrates that he pays no attention to what anybody says in this place. I can assure him that he enjoys reciprocal rights in that respect. What I said the last time I raised the question was that, as a democratic society, we had to draw a distinction between the political right to act in a certain way-to establish neo-nazi schools, Accelerated Christian Education schools, or Hare Krishna schools-and the right to receive unlimited Federal financial support for such schools. That is a very important distinction which of course has escaped the attention of Senator Martyr.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that a collective decision must be made by a responsible authority in this society as to which schools shall be entitled to receive Commonwealth funds . I point out to Senator Peter Baume that it strikes me as a very great irony indeed that while all these schools which are promoting ideas that I believe are totally unacceptable to most Australians-the crucial point being that those ideas are promoted at the expense of the Australian taxpayer-an Aboriginal community school in Alice Springs, the Yipirinya School, has been denied registration. That school has been established for some years. It is a genuine community school and is offering a bilingual education to children from fringe camps in Alice Springs. Probably Senator Peter Baume has visited the school. I have and I know that many honourable senators have. It is a legitimate school whose program and curriculum relate to the community that it serves. It has been refused registration by the Northern Territory Government which, of course, is of a political complexion which makes it a coalition partner of Senator Peter Baume. The Yipirinya School in Alice Springs has been refused registration by the Northern Territory Government and therefore is unable to receive Commonwealth funding. At the same time a vast variety of exotic schools, whose purposes I believe do not fit properly into the democratic framework of our society, is able to receive registration and Commonwealth funds. If Senator Baume as Commonwealth Minister for Education is complacent about that situation I can assure him that the Federal Australian Labor Party is not.

Senator Baume is probably going to point out that the Australian Education Council, which is composed of State and Federal Education Ministers, is examining the problem of registration of schools. But the information that the Opposition has been able to garner about the operation of that inquiry suggests to us that the AEC examination of the criteria for the registration of new private schools is more an exercise in seeking uniform criteria across Australia than a hard look at rationalising education resources and ensuring that new private schools have acceptable curricula and do not duplicate facilities offered by government schools in the same area. I believe that this is a very serious matter. I am heartened to see that today's media has addressed its attention to it. I will be very interested to see whether Senator Baume believes that the proliferation of schools able to receive Commonwealth funds, as now documented in a Commonwealth report, is precisely what was intended by his Government's funding policies.

I turn briefly to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1982. Of course, in the area of tertiary education it must be said that the bankruptcy of the Fraser Government's entire education policy has been exposed in the recently published Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's report entitled 'Learning and Earning'. I remind honourable senators that that report shows a number of alarming things including the following: An alarming drop of 18 per cent in the proportion of young people proceeding directly to higher education; a very big loss in high ability students; a serious decline in the availability of student assistance; and an accelerated deterioration in the prospects for jobs and apprenticeships as a result of the current crisis.

The Government's performance in the tertiary education area has concentrated on economy rather than education. In the current circumstances of educational decline as documented by this report, the Government's policy can be described only as inept. Of course, I remind honourable senators of the excellent report on the tenure of academics brought down by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. That report also documented the effects of reduced funding in the tertiary education area. Those effects include: Inflexibility in the staffing of our tertiary institutions; a lowering of teaching standard; a reduction in the rank of courses available to students; and, of course, a lowering in research standards.

The major initiative of the Fraser Government in the tertiary education area has been to demand the amalgamation of a large number of tertiary institutions. This, of course, was one of the last gasps of the so-called razor gang committee . The amalgamation which was inflicted on a number of tertiary institutions throughout this country was, by and large, not developed as a result of educational policy but has been done in the belief or in the rather desperate hope, I suppose, that these measures will save money. Of course, the reality is that these imposed amalgamations will save little money, if any, and will be educationally damaging not to all of the institutions but certainly to many of them.

What has happened and what is provided for in the Bills before us this evening are that the Government is going to withhold money from those institutions which the Government demands amalgamate. The threat, of course, is that the funding to these institutions will be lost unless they follow the instructions laid down by the Government. The purpose of the amendment to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, which I will be moving on behalf of the Opposition at the Committee stage, is to safeguard the funding to these institutions. The institutions which are currently under threat in this way include: The Armidale College of Advanced Education and the University of New England in Armidale; the University of Newcastle and the Newcastle College of Advanced Education; the Milperra College of Advanced Education and the Hawthorn Institute of Education in Melbourne; and the Orange Agricultural College and the Mitchell College of Advanced Education. In many of these cases the amalgamations will cause serious problems. More importantly, a number of institutions are being asked to compromise their educational objectives to try to achieve the Government's dubious economic objectives. Of course, the Opposition strongly objects to this. For this reason we will be moving the amendments which I foreshadowed.

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill creates a new fund called the National Unallocated Grant for Higher Education. As a result of this amending legislation grants for 1983 and 1984 for the institutions undergoing amalgamation are to be withheld until these amalgamations are completed. Very briefly, the view of the Opposition is this: We have grave reservations about using this kind of mechanism to achieve the amalgamations. If the amalgamations are achieved, if there is agreement between the Federal Minister and the responsible State Minister then, of course, we have no objections to the amalgamations, and we have no objections to the funding being made available in this manner. But if no agreement is reached-as I have said many problems will arise as a result of these forced amalgamations-between the responsible State Minister and the Federal Minister then, of course, we cannot condone the withholding of funds. The purpose of our amendment will be to make an automatic allocation of an appropriate level of funding available to these institutions in the event of no agreement being reached by the State Minister and the Federal Minister. I will explain at the Committee stage of the debate how this amendment will work. I have outlined the views of the Opposition in relation to these two Bills. I have said that the Opposition wishes to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1982. That amendment reads:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that grants to all schools should be fully adjusted to take account of cost increases experienced by those schools'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of my time in the Senate, which is now over eight years, we have had a number of different education debates. They have ranged over a wide variety of subjects. SPEECH.PARA: I will pay some attention to some of the detail of Senator Ryan's speech because I think there has to be some comment on it. But I will go past the content of her speech and touch on a couple of other subjects which I consider to be of real educational moment. I am very sad that so much of the education debate in Australia in 1982 is taken up with this divisive debate on whether or not all non-government schools should be receiving some funding from Government sources and, if so, how much. I am particularly disturbed at the way in which the argument against funding of all non-government schools is advanced by those who put forward that argument. The term that is most frequently used is that the 'wealthy non-government schools' are under attack. These are the schools which, under a Labor government, would not receive government funding. They paint a picture of a large group of schools which would not attract subsidies or would not attract the same level of subsidy under a Labor government.

The people of Australia and the parents of students of schools in Australia, particularly the parents of students in non-government schools, are entitled to know what the Labor Party's policy is on this subject. TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right, is it?

SPEECH.PARA: I must turn to the theme in a large part of Senator Ryan's speech this evening which re- iterated, in essence, what she said last Wednesday in the Senate in the debate on the matter of public importance raised by her on the subject of education. She made some extraordinary statements. I had some difficulty in believing my ears that we were hearing an education policy and that the Labor Party in opposition would seriously suggest the sorts of things that were suggested in Senator Ryan's speech.
