That State Government met that problem that there was a suggestion that some weirdo sort of group would set up these sorts of institutions. When the purpose of the Bill was explained, it was accepted by the Parliament and the Queensland public.

I suggest to Senator Ryan that State governments are pretty sensitive to the allegation that public funds would be going to fund weirdo groups-I was going to say 'offbeat', but I do not think even that is strong enough-these fringe groups that are not genuinely interested in providing the essential basic education which should be provided in every school. The State governments, I suggest, would be anything but anxious to be spreading around those funds that they consider to be too scarce at the best of times to groups which were not providing an education that those State governments say is compulsory for all children.

What would a Labor government do? Senator Ryan did not go quite to the length of telling us. She gave us some general suggestion that someone had made on the subject of registration of schools. But if the Commonwealth is to enter into this area, what would the Labor Party do? The basic criterion for registration of a school is surely that it gives the fundamental education that we expect and , indeed, demand that every child in Australia must receive-not just 'should' receive, because education is compulsory. How far past that can a government go? Can it tell the States what should be taught in their curricula in these subjects? Is it suggested that some Commonwealth body should have some oversight of the basic curricula? Is it suggested that a Commonwealth government should have an oversight of other matters?

There are subjects offered, courses offered and other things offered in non- government schools which are additional to what are offered in government schools, which are their basic raison d'etre. Those things we accept. We accept religious instruction in schools which have a connection with religion. We accept it, be it Christian, Jewish, Muslim or Hari Krishna. Governments have not stepped in in Australia and said 'That religious teaching is acceptable, but that is not'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't.
—Senator Ryan was suggesting, as far as I am concerned-
—The Federal Government cannot make laws in relation to religion .

—Did Senator Macklin hear Senator Ryan speak? She was taking issue with the detail of the attitudes of religious teaching in some of the schools to which she referred and which she was suggesting should not be receiving government funding. It would be quite proper for Senator Ryan to raise the issue of whether certain things should be taught to our children, but she must realise what she is opening up. This is what the Minister for Education was trying to persuade her when he was asking her during her speech: 'Do you realise what you are saying?'
—It is a matter of trying to close the bottomless pit you have opened up.

—Senator Ryan cannot use that broad brush. She cannot tell the people of Australia that there are non-government schools receiving public funds that she thinks should not be receiving them, give a basis that she thinks would alarm the Australian public sufficiently to persuade them to the Labor Party's view on funding of non-government schools, and not tell us precisely what she is at in relation to all of them. If one is to take issue with the teachings of one religion which sets up a school one has to take issue with all of them. I have actually been approached by that religious group on the subject of education funding. It has discussed the subject of education funding with me. It has not asked me to make any representations; we just engaged in a conversation. I queried the subjects that are offered at its school. I was told that it offers the basic educational curriculum, that it complies with what non-government schools are required to comply with in terms of offering the education in certain areas that we demand all children should have. I cannot defend that school in detail, but I was interested in whether it was offering the general basic education that we require for our children. I was told that it was and that on that basis it got some funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan went on to say that it was a matter of concern that anyone can set up a school for any purpose. It is not so that anyone can set up a school for any purpose. It may be a matter of concern to Senator Ryan that certain religious groups take certain views in relation to girls. I would share that concern but I do not think one should pursue that issue in the education debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.

—It is very dangerous. Senator Ryan may well have a view on the subject of what should be the views of other people towards the relative superiority of the female sex over the male sex. It may be of concern to me. But there are other issues with which other people could find as much concern. They could take exception to what the Jewish religion teaches children in its schools .
—True.

—I say to Senator Tate that it is quite possible. One has to face that fact. If one is to introduce that subject in the general terms that Senator Ryan introduced it into this debate one has to be prepared to pursue it to its conclusion or drop it. Senator Ryan was invited to drop the subject. She insisted on pursuing it and got herself into worse trouble. She referred to the vast variety of exotic schools which do not fit into the democratic structure of our society. For heaven's sake, we are talking about eduction presented in our schools. If they do not fit into the democratic structure of our society, does that mean that what is being taught in those school classrooms is anti- democratic? Is that what Senator Ryan is suggesting? Some parents would think that some of the views put by some teachers in other schools are rather anti- democratic too. I have heard parents getting pretty hostile about what their children are taught in government schools. I do not know whether they are right or wrong, but we accept that certain things happen. I know that if a government were to step in on that matter it would be accused of political censorship in the classroom. Senator Ryan got herself right into that area. Which schools do not fit into the democratic structure of our society, why do they not fit in, who says they do not and what is the answer? One cannot use those general terms to put down the Government's funding policy, particularly in relation to non- government schools, and raise these bogies without answering those questions.

SPEECH.PARA: The logical conclusion to the issues that Senator Ryan raised could possibly be , in some people's view, to have no religious instruction; in other words, to allow nothing to happen in any non-government school that does not happen in a government classroom. That is one possible logical conclusion. If Senator Ryan is to continue in that vein in the education debate in the Senate she will have to be prepared to be challenged on those issues and to answer those challenges. I will listen with great interest to what Senator Ryan says on behalf of the Australian Labor Party in response to those points.

It was not my intention when I rose this evening to spend 20 minutes on Senator Ryan's speech. It was my intention to spend some time on the education debate to which I referred at the beginning of my speech. I shall do so now in a truncated form. One of the issues in addition to funding that I would like to see the Senate debating-it quite properly debates funding but, as I said earlier, it has become a sterile and divisive debate when it is confined to that-is the challenges to education in Australia in the 1980s. The challenges are great; they are debated by many educators. Nobody has any specific answers, but they are urgent issues. They are issues which essentially, I suppose, will have to be addressed in particular by State governments. Those of us in the Parliament who are involved in education have a responsibility to raise those issues with the Commonwealth Government to see whether it believes there is anything relevant that it can do or would want to do in these areas.

The two greatest challenges to school education in Australia today are the impact of the technological revolution as it is called-technological change-and the impact of fundamental social change in our society. In the latter context we have debated on a number of occasions in the Senate the implications for our educational system either as a source of youth unemployment or as a cure for it. But other social change is taking place also. In the Senate a couple of weeks ago I referred to the historic disability of women in Australian society and to how we have a problem as a result of major change in the 1970s which was compounded by historic factors. The simple fact is that the majority of adult women in Australian society have on average a very low level of education. The great majority of women over the age of 40 in Australia have little more than primary school education-basic literacy and numeracy.

That it could have happened is bad enough, but that historical fact is compounded by the many one parent families resulting from the modern trend of a high rate of divorce or from other factors such as widowhood. In most of these families the mother is the parent. Our society is demanding in terms of the educational standards that it sets for people seeking employment. These women very badly need access to a reasonable level of remuneration so that they can rear families, and they do not have an education that fits them for it. If they decide to approach education in their mature years to seek better skills they find that the institutional hurdles they have to clear are enormous. They are not welcome in our high schools. A number of them are attending classes in high schools with teenage students, but that is a very small number. They are not welcome because they disrupt timetables. They do not fit into the model of what our high schools have been, for students and in administration, for decades now. I suggest that we have to take this new social factor into account when looking at what we should expect of our schooling system.

I think one could look with some value at the Tasmanian community college. It would be valuable to look seriously at whether the upper levels of our high schools-let us say the last two years of high schooling for students in the 16 to 18 years age range-could be so structured and opened up that adults, both men and women, who these days need to return to school had access to them to reach a higher level of education without the very practical institutional hurdles that are now put in their way. I believe that could be done without detriment to the education of our teenagers as they proceed through their normal schooling process.

It only stands to reason that if women, or indeed men, who may be on a pension and are raising a young family want to go back to school the most reasonable time for them to have that opportunity would be while school is in, when their children are at school. Virtually the only alternative of attending evening classes when their children are at home and need their attention and time-indeed , if they are to have someone else's attention and time it would cost money that those parents do not have-is not a reasonable alternative. I think that is one matter that has to be looked at. Social change and single parent families are not the only reasons though. Also technological change means that a lot of low level skill work will in the future be done more and more by machines rather than people and many people recently entered into the work force will need to return to school to get a higher level of skills than the low or virtually non- existent skills that they have at the moment. Those people need access to that sort of education and they need it in a reasonable way.

In my experience it has been mainly the tertiary sector that has been debating the future of education in Australia, looking with some worry and puzzlement at the phenomenon of technological change and asking: 'What should we be planning for in our educational institutions in Australia in 20 years time?' That has been my major experience as someone who gets involved in a lot of those conferences and discussions. In my opinion the area at which we should be looking most closely is the schooling level, particularly the upper high schooling level. That is where the real challenge lies. Of course, some of it lies in the technical area and will continue to do so. We must face the fact that already there are very many people in Australia today who do not have what we now consider to be basic education because basic education standards have risen in recent years. Such people had what were basic education standards when they went to school but sadly they have been left behind by a society which has changed in a way that nobody could have foretold when they were at school.

They are the sorts of subjects to which I think we should be properly addressing ourselves in the Senate. As I said when I started on this subject, they are issues largely for determination in detail and in the final instance by State governments. I believe it is the responsibility of all of us who have some influence in educational policy and who care about education to turn our minds to this issue and to try jointly and as apolitically as we can to come up with solutions to that problem which is the real challenge to education in Australia today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate we are discussing the grants made by the Commonwealth to the States in relation to schools and tertiary institutions. I wish to spend some of the time available to me on both the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill. In the debates that we have had in this place from time to time, I think there is progressively coming to the fore some realistic considerations of the problems that this country is confronting in its education institutions. One of the important aspects that we ought always to remember is that the problems that we face today were not created today. In fact , they were created by the types of policies in place in this country in the last 10 years or 15 years. Today, the problems are the fruit of those types of educational policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The criticisms that have been levelled at those policies are well documented, such as the under-funding in terms of pupils in Australian schools in comparison with countries of comparable levels around the world. Those low level fundings that we provided in the 1960s and in the very early 1970s had only partly started to be redressed in 1972 when the Labor Government came to power. This is so through to the present time. I say 'only partly redressed' because once those additional funds went to schools there was necessarily some falling down in terms of expenditure in the schools. It was relatively easy because of the dramatic increase to point to wastage and to areas where money was misspent. Those types of things occur and occur in any institution. But the unfortunate thing about them is that attention was applied to them on the part of some sections of the media. This meant that almost immediately we had a community feeling which started to arise that perhaps we were not getting value for our dollar.

Governments of all political persuasions must respond in some way to the general feelings of the community. The problems with those particular feelings within the community is that they latched on to something which had not been a feature of the Australian educational funding scene, that is, large amounts of money were being spent in an attempt to change the institution, to upgrade it and to modernise it. Therefore I believe that those types of community movements allow governments-indeed in many cases force governments-to take a less sanguine view of the usefulness of massive funding to educational institutions. I think that those problems have lasted to the present day. They are now much more difficult problems to deal with because the need for change, flexibility and upgrading is more dramatic than it has ever been.

I wish to raise one area as an example of how when we do make a step forward, a step that a lot of people in the country have been suggesting, at the same time we manage, because of past educational problems, to create massive problems for ourselves while we are trying to get some advance. I refer in particular to computer and mathematics education. It serves well as an illustration of some of the difficulties of the educational scene that the Commonwealth, quite rightly through the Schools Commission and other instrumentalities, particularly through its own Department of Education, is seeking in co-operation with the States to upgrade massively computer education in this country. That is to be welcomed, applauded and supported.

The unfortunate occurrence, though, is something that may not have been foreseen and which certainly leads me to have grave doubts about what may be happening in the immediate future in these areas. What is going to occur and is occurring is this. As we manage to introduce into our schools more competent and more useful software in terms of hands-on experience and computers we gather mathematic teachers for that particular instruction. They are generally the ones who are used in the computer area. If one were to look at the availability of mathematics teachers in Australia one would know-we have known for some time- that we have a shortage of them. One of the things that people do not realise is that the vast bulk of mathematics in our schools is taught by teachers who teach only one class of mathematics in their teaching load. What this means, quite simply, is that the vast bulk of mathematics teachers are not specialist mathematics teachers. They are competent in maths; they are competent to take the classes that they are teaching but they are not specialist teachers in the area. More and more we are drawing on our specialist teachers to support computer education. Meanwhile we are leaving mathematics education to the non- specialist in our schools; often, for example, to an English teacher or a history teacher who will pick up a maths lesson here or there. Those problems have not been caused by any government in the recent past. They are indeed the coming home to roost of very bad, very short-sighted, policies that were implemented in the 1960s and 1970s.

In particular one can look now at tertiary institutions in those areas and note a dramatic decline in the number of higher degrees taken in mathematics and science. At the very time when our country needs to be much more than just moving and, in fact, needs to be galloping towards getting itself a highly skilled scientific and mathematic base we are, in fact, decreasing the number of students going into higher degrees in science and mathematics. This is an extraordinary occurrence for a country such as ours which maintains that it can become a high technology society. I believe the example I give has poignancy. With a decline in those science based courses at the tertiary level we also have an increasing inability on the part of our education departments, both at university and college of advanced education level, to attract students into the teaching strands of science and mathematics.

I have cast around in relation to the projections that the various departments of education in the various universities and major CAEs give for next year. They all project a further decline again in students going into those teaching areas. If anything should send a chill up and down one's spine it is that fact. We talk constantly about the fact that we probably have more teachers than we need, yet that is not the way to talk. We should talk in specific terms. Do we have enough mathematics teachers? Do we have enough science teachers? That is the way to talk. When one looks at every State and every institution we discover that we do not have enough teachers in those areas. We do not even have enough teachers to service our current requirements, let alone to expand our base. That is terrifying for the type of society we believe we need to establish to bring about economic growth in this country.

If one looks further, not only at the number of students who are going into those courses but also at the number of students who are going into all tertiary institutions, as a percentage of our population, we find a decline. In 1977 the figure was 1.32 per cent; in 1978 it was 1.3 per cent; in 1979 it was 1.25 per cent; in 1980 it was 1.21 per cent; and in 1981 it was 1.18 per cent. In other words, there has been a progressive decline in the percentage of our population entering our tertiary institutions. Where are we going in this country in terms of our education if, in fact, we can look with equanimity at those devastating percentages, at that decline in the percentage of our population going into our tertiary institutions?

I have said publicly in a number of places that the debate about retention rates is misplaced. We are not concerned about dragooning young people into necessarily taking on further courses at school or going directly into tertiary institutions. Indeed, we know from education research that a pause between high school and entering a tertiary institution is a good thing, not a bad thing. So the pertinent figures are not necessarily those of the number of young people entering our tertiary institutions straight from school. In fact, I have argued professionally and will go on arguing that it would be much better if we did not have anybody going straight from school into a tertiary institution. That can be argued on a whole host of bases and not only on an economic basis. It can also be argued on good, educational philosophy grounds.

The relevant percentage is whether our total percentage of people in those tertiary institutions is growing as a percentage of the population. It is not, as the figures I have just read indicate. It is declining. That is the worry; that is the concern. The percentage is declining in those areas I have just mentioned. I have a range of figures on the declining student load in relation to higher degrees in mathematics and science and they show again a decline. We must stop the decline, turn the situation around and move ahead. Moreover, we must do so rapidly, by way of crash programs. It is not a State matter. To turn those figures around ought to be a Commonwealth priority. It is the responsibility of the Commonwealth to make sure that we have an educated population to support the type of economic society that we believe we will need. We must remember that we have only 18 years left before we reach the year 2000 and that in the interim more than four million young Australians will leave school. We are not talking about the Never Never. We are talking about the immediate future. It is the programs we put in place today that will bear fruit at that time. If they do not people will look back and say, 'It was the programs that were put in place in the 1980s that caused the problems that we face today' .

I wish to refer to only one of the matters in relation to schools that Senator Ryan raised. It was important that she should have done so. In raising the issue of the funding of particular types of non-government schools she was possibly skating out onto a lake with very thin ice, without necessarily knowing how to get back. Her effort was certainly worth while and I applaud her courage in raising the matter. It is one that is of concern to and a subject of debate in the community. The way in which we handle it is important. I repeat that it is a community issue and I congratulate Senator Ryan for having the courage to raise it. I admit that I have steered clear of it myself.

Now that she has raised it, I will express the viewpoint of the Australian Democrats concerning a highly contentious area, one that will become more so in the ensuing years. The Australian Democrats do not as a party necessarily subscribe to many of the views that have been expressed by those fringe groups or to what they are teaching in schools. Indeed, we find them abhorrent, but that is not the issue. In a democracy we have to accept a whole range of views, even those with which we do not agree or which we dislike. We have to allow them to exist. A school may be established on the basis of the beliefs of a particular fringe sect such as the Moral Majority of the United States, to which Senator Ryan referred. I find the views of that organisation, as it exists at the moment in the United States, personally abhorrent. Equally, the suggestions that come from it are suggestions that the Australian Democrats have spent their entire existence fighting, and which they will continue to fight. Nevertheless, they may not be breaking any State law. I raise the point with Senator Ryan-on many occasions it has been put to me and I have looked into a number of these organisations-that many of them are running awfully close to the limit of many State laws. I refer not to laws having to do with education but, basically, to those that have to do with the treatment of children.

We have State laws that apply not only to schools but also to parents in their own homes. Parents have not an absolute right to deal with their children as they will. There are in our society very strict laws to protect and nurture children, to allow them to grow as useful citizens. If the natural parents do not maintain the degree of care of their children that the community holds to be reasonable, the children are taken from them. In most States such laws are pretty tough. Some of these fringe groups may be sailing awfully close to the wind in that regard. I must admit that on the occasions I have examined such organisations as far as I could determine they had not infringed such laws, but I must say that they went awfully close to doing so.

I believe that is the area in which community concern is currently based. There is concern for those children in terms of the type of treatment they are getting in some of those schools. If we move beyond that and think of the types of viewpoints that will be put to those children, I am afraid we have to come down on the basis that we are a democratic society and, much as we as a society may not like and may fight against those views and much as we may hope that those views will never prevail in our society or even be regarded as a reasonable minority voice in the community, we must still, as the Australian Democrats will , allow and fight for the right of those people to express those minority views within the society. The Australian Democrats, as a political minority group in the community, probably are more sensitive than most to that type of view. We believe that we express a reasonable minority view within the community. We believe that we offer an alternative to people within the community. It would hardly be in keeping with the philosophy of our party, which supports very strongly the notion of democracy, to attempt to rub out viewpoints. I remind Senator Ryan that, whilst today we may consider those views as being extreme minority views, there was a time when Christianity was considered to be an extreme minority view.

The question about funding such schools is extremely important. It really makes no difference to us whether those views be expressed by a minority Christian sect or by a majority mainstream Christian group. It makes no difference to us whether they be expressed by the Hare Khrishna or Catholics within the community . If the principle can apply to Catholics it must apply to other sects in the community providing they remain within the laws of the land that govern all relationships between adults and children. Once again, I am indebted to Senator Ryan for publicly raising this matter. I believe that possibly we can now start a fruitful debate in this area and, I hope, we can get on the table a range of views to see whether we can develop a community consensus on this issue. It probably will be a divisive issue for some time to come, but I think it is useful for it to have been raised.

I raise a point in relation to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance ) Amendment Bill. The item of concern here is amalgamations. I have already expressed a concern about where we ought to be going in respect of the overall funding of these institutions. We constantly have expressed the view that tertiary institutions provide us with one of our main life support systems to a reasonable economic future. There are currently available to us within our developed tertiary sector a range of opportunities that we have not pursued vigorously. I have referred in depth and quite extensively on other occasions to the necessity for the individual funding of programs, particularly in the area of biotechnology. We are still not doing that. We are not doing it in anywhere near the type of imaginative, flexible and far-reaching way that we ought to be doing it. We are still investing in pipelines, roads and a whole host of other areas. We still do not have any new imaginative and far-reaching programs in which to invest the intelligence, skills and imagination of our population. I point out to the Senate that this is not the result of lack of imagination or ingenuity within the Australian community.

It has been said many times that the entire computer industry around the world is in fact based on fundamental research which was done by Australians. Some of the research was carried out here but the majority of it was carried out overseas by Australians. In the biotechnology field Australia has been the leader in a number of specific fundamental areas for some 20 years. We do not lack skills. For example, in Melbourne just after World War II the second mainframe computer in the world was developed. Australia was only something like six to nine months behind the United States in that technological breakthrough. Australia had the skills. How did that industry develop? The computer industry is now the third largest industry in the country. But Australia's second largest import, after petroleum, is computers. That is extraordinary. The computer industry is our third largest industry. It comes after the energy and motor vehicle industries. Yet computers are our second largest import. After we have paid for our fuel, the next bill we have to pay is for our computers. That is a most extraordinary situation for a country which was in the lead when this industry got going. If we invest heavily now in biotechnology we can build on the breakthroughs that Australian scientists have made and give Australia the number one growth industry in the world-an industry which is providing the major part of the growth in the United States economy at the present time, an industry which has put Switzerland's standard of living first in the world, and an industry which is putting Japan high up while Australia is slipping further and further behind.

I stress again that money spent in the area of tertiary education is money invested in our best resource-human capital. We have the skills, we have the know-how and we have the base. All we need now is the courage to spend money and to invest. In that way we could have a future comparable with that of those other countries. It is in this area of such vital national concern that this Government and the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) bear a heavy burden. They must respond imaginatively.

I wish to move an amendment on behalf of the Australian Democrats to the motion for the second reading of the States Grants (Tertiary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1982, which we are now debating technically. I move:
At end of motion add:

', but the Senate is of the opinion that it is inappropriate for the Government to threaten the cessation of funds to those institutions which have not presented acceptable proposals for amalgamation to the Minister by the end of this year, and that therefore the Bill should be amended to provide fixed funding levels for the institutions listed in Schedule 18, instead of leaving funds in the National Unallocated Grants to be distributed at the Minister's discretion'.

This is similar to the amendment formally to be moved by Senator Ryan on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. I will elaborate a little more in the Committee stage but the idea is simply that we do not believe that the Government should make a threat that it does not intend to carry out. I do not believe that this Government intends to cut the throat of an institution to make it healthy. I will elaborate on that point at the Committee stage. Since my time has almost run out, I foreshadow that I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the other Bill we are discussing cognately, the States Grants ( Schools Assistance) Bill 1982. This will have to be moved as an amendment to the Labor Party's amendment, which has been foreshadowed already by Senator Ryan. I foreshadow that I shall move that at the end of the Labor Party's amendment the following words be added:

, and that increased Commonwealth funding should be provided to promote the language facilities and to assist the language teachers at all schools so that, by 1990, a national language policy can be implemented through which a second language is accepted as an integral part of the learning of every Australian.

This proposition has been discussed widely in a number of national forums by both the Minister and Senator Chipp. It has been discussed in this place and I believe has general wide support from Ministers and from all honourable senators who wish to see Australia moving towards acceptance of that type of national language program. At the appropriate time I will formally move that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not take too much of the time of the Senate, but in the debate on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill I wish to express some concern that I have about the way in which the present Government's philosophical approach to education has allowed a rise in the number of private schools in the system. I note that according to the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette there has been a rise since 1979 of 139 in the number of non-government schools in Australia. That has taken place at a time when enrolments in schools are generally declining. I note also that 29 of the non-government schools built between 1979 and the current year are based in Victoria. I believe this utilisation of scarce funds to duplicate bricks, mortar and other facilities already in existence within the education system is a waste of taxpayers' money at a time when government school enrolments are declining. Because of that, facilities in many government schools are declining; yet down the street or across the town we see new non-government schools being erected and staffed and provided with all the necessary facilities. In my view, that is a squandering of taxpayers' money. I have noticed it more in rural areas where it stands out a little more clearly than in the cities or metropolitan areas. In western Victoria, at Hamilton High School between 1979 and 1982 there was a decline of 139 students. Yet in 1981 a non-government secondary school was built there.
—What do you think are the reasons for the decline?

—I think it is the pill and perhaps that people are moving away from country towns, which has been an historical development over the last 20, 30 or 40 years. The facts are that one government secondary school had a decline in pupils of 139; yet under the philosophical approach of this Government to education another secondary school was built in the town. The same situation applies in places such as Mildura, Shepparton, Warrigal, Murtoa, Nhill, Leongatha, Kerang, Portland, Baxter and Tawonga, to name just a few of the towns in Victoria where this philosophical approach is having its way and where government school numbers are declining. Yet this Government is prepared to fund another school in the same district or in the same town. For example, between 1979 and 1982, in the town of Murtoa the State primary school has seen a decline of 50 pupils. Yet in 1981 a new non-government school opened to pick up the equivalent of those 50 pupils. Again, I believe that is a waste of taxpayers' money. As someone pointed out to me recently, this sort of philosophy divides children not only by creed, country, culture and colour but also within creed and colour-in effect, a nation's children divided within themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I express also my concern over the development of so many so-called Christian schools. Over the recent period since 1979, it seems that more Christian schools have been built in our society than there are Christians in that society, if one wants to be fairly specific about the term 'Christian'. I will read through the list, as it appears in Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of 30 November. The list includes Mulgrave-Bethel Christian School, Bundoora-Northside Christian College, Morwell-Morwell Christian School, Warranwood-Life Christian Academy, Bendigo-Creek Street Christian College, and Campbell's Creek-Olivet Christian College. One can drive through Campbell's Creek, blink twice and not know that one had passed through the joint. Yet it has a Christian college. The list continues with Geelong North-Geelong Christian School, Maribyrnong-Moonee Vale Christian School, Monbulk-Mountain District Christian School, Highton-Christian College, Highton, and Mernda-Plenty Valley Christian School. A whole swath of these so-called Christian schools are being opened up in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that worry you?

—It does worry me when I wonder about the sort of culture and whatever else they may teach inside those schools. I note that the shadow Minister for Education, Mr Dawkins, expressed his concern about so many of these schools which, as he stated, have origins in American fundamental Christian traditions. In my view, Australian customs and culture have already suffered at the hands of the American invasion via advertising, big business and, in particular, television-the Americanisation of Australia, as I describe it. Now they are apparently to be given the opportunity to inculcate Australian children in the classroom.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might help the debate if, to start, I set down briefly five principles on which the Government bases its education policies which have been the subject of so much discussion tonight. We set down equality of opportunity, equity in funding, relevance in what schools offer, excellence of offerings and the development of national cohesion and identity. I believe that those principles are principles which would be endorsed by many Australians and which underpin our funding in education, and certainly in schools which underpin our contribution this year of nearly $1,500m as our share of educational funding.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the funding of education in Australia, I want to spell out four other principles which underpin the role of the Commonwealth as a funding agency and which, therefore, underpin the policies which are the subject of the Bills which we have been discussing. First, there is not one partner but there are three partners in funding schools in Australia. Those three partners are the Commonwealth Government, the State governments and those private sources which contribute to education. That partnership is an established fact. The relative contributions of the partners may vary or they may evolve over time. But that is a fact-three partners, not one. Any assessment of the resource position of schools must focus on the total contribution of the three partners. Our analysis concentrates on the three partners. The Australian Labor Party analysis assiduously avoids taking into account the contributions of the private sector or the State governments and therefore provides an inaccurate analysis.

The second principle which underpins our funding of schools is that all students, wherever they go to school, are entitled to support from both Commonwealth and State governments. We believe that is a principle which underlies our funding of education for all Australian children. These Bills provide for that principle to be honoured. Thirdly, we believe that for all schools basic support should be provided by governments, together with additional support according to need. The fourth principle is that we believe that there should be proper accountability, both educational accountability and financial accountability, as part of the deal which underlies our funding. We need to know how the funds are used, and, if possible, we have to know what the educational outcomes are, and we have to know how those outcomes relate to the objectives for which the funds were provided. That is the prudent way to know what has happened to money, and if we are contributors to the government and non -government systems, we might equally ask that question in relation to expenditure in the government system as in the non-government system.

Against the background of those goals in education and those principles, and against those commitments, the proposals of our political opponents really can be assessed and understood. They do not include in their presentations or their analyses any acknowledgment of the contribution by the States as partners in educational provision, and on that ground alone their figures are false and incomplete. Our opponents also assert that government schools are poor, are badly off, and they assert that independent schools, non-government schools, are wealthy. Those are largely false accusations. Our opponents have apparently forgotten that our object is the welfare of the whole nation, of all schools. We have produced some figures. Senator Martin discussed them tonight. I shall not go over them in detail, but they demonstrate the falsity of the two beliefs-that government schools are poor, and that non-government are wealthy. I remind honourable senators that if we look at the question of pupil-teacher ratios between 1974 and 1981, we see that government schools at secondary level had the best pupil-teacher ratios in Australia. So if we are talking about class size, we know which are the rich schools at secondary level. The best class sizes are in government schools. The worst class sizes are, of course, in the Catholic schools. Our funding is directed largely towards them.

Looking at total cash expenditure across Australia between government schools and non-government schools, we find that the government schools, again, have the best income of all the schools. Looking at all of the sources, we see that the government schools are best off. Certainly at the secondary level they have most money going in each year. Again, it is the Catholic systems which are the poorest. An analysis which has been based upon the fallacy that government schools are poorest is an analysis which leads one to the wrong kinds of policies and the wrong kinds of levels.

It is disappointing that the Australian Labor Party persists in ignoring the contribution of the three sectors. Looking at the whole picture, it is simply not possible to assert, as our opponents do, that government schools are poorer. I just wish they would stop because it is an inaccurate analysis. It is about time we put the state aid debate and that kind of program aside. Ten years ago we tried to settle this issue. We should concentrate our attention in this debate on the pursuit of educational objectives.

I must pay tribute to Senator Macklin. He addressed a number of educational issues. I cannot say that Senator Ryan in her speech did anything but make us very sad. I believe that in talking as she did about certain groups on non- government schools she raised the very worst kind of illiberal, unreasonable, inappropriate issues. I hope that people will read Hansard because what she said will stand on its own. She spoke for the Australian Labor Party, she was supported by Senator Primmer in this chamber and she was supported in the Press this morning by Mr Dawkins. I do not want to send my children to accelerated Christian education schools-that is not my cup of tea-but to have Senator Ryan assert that on the basis of their beliefs they are not fit to receive funding, that should be put to either a political or a religious test to determine their eligibility for funding, does no credit to the honourable senator or to her party. She made the kind of illiberal statement that I believe will not help the educational debate or what we are trying to do.

Any school, to receive funding, must demonstrate its viability, parental demand , that it is registrable and that it is a non-profit organisation. The fact that a school is registrable means that it is acceptable to a State as an educational institution. The honourable senator really suggests that we should look behind State registration and apply tests that are clearly based on the religious or political beliefs of those who run the school. That proposition is entirely unacceptable. I make one final point about non-government schools. Why do parents choose them? They might have narrower offerings. Many of them are in worse surroundings. They have larger class sizes, they have fewer dollars coming in. The parents have to contribute from their after-tax disposable income. There is every kind of disincentive one could think of, yet parents in Australia, for one reason or another, are flocking to enrol their children in non-government schools. Whatever the reasons one wants to attribute to this, it is a fact that should be understood and analysed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the reasons?

—Parents are seeing value in sending their children to those schools. I regret that I cannot take the time to discuss this matter with Senator Chipp. Perhaps we could sit down and talk about it some time. I move on to the question that was alluded to by Senator Macklin as the main area of concern to him. I refer to the question of the amalgamations and the way in which the Government is approaching them. This matter is dealt with in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. I assert that what we are doing is in the best interests of the educational future, the educational mission and the educational possibilities of the institutions which are affected . It has been alleged that the Commonwealth Government has never set out its reasons for requiring the consolidation of certain colleges of advanced education. That is not true. It is appropriate for me tonight to set down the reasons for the amalgamations. A dominating factor in higher education in Australia in the past few years has been the falling demand for teacher education. This is largely for demographic reasons. The population of that age cohort is dropping. The number of pupils in the schools is no longer growing as it did for about 20 years from the mid-1950s. The Commonwealth Government, when it realised this fall in the need for teacher training, had broadly two options open to it: It could cease to fund certain teacher training institutions-it could in fact close them-and that at least would reduce the number of places and would have been one appropriate response to the falling demand for teacher education, or it could continue to fund their educational programs on the condition that there be a consolidation of the institutions into larger and stronger units.

SPEECH.PARA: We looked at the two options, canvassed them and came down in favour of the second option; that we should move to consolidation for a number of reasons which I will set out. That advice was accepted. The arrangements were set in train and an announcement that these consolidations should occur was made in April 1981. We are now at the end of 1982. It has been argued in public-not here in the Senate tonight-that we have rushed the matter. These decisions were announced in April 1981. They were made known to all the institutions involved. A number of them, I must say, did nothing for as long as they could, hoping the issue would go away, but we laid down what was required almost one and two- thirds years ago. Few people who knew what was going on in higher education were surprised that the issue had become urgent or that we took the action we did. For many years it was obvious that this was needed. In 1972 the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts, in a report which led to teachers colleges becoming colleges of advanced education, stressed the need for the consolidation of small teacher education institutions into larger units. The process was advocated also in 1973 in the Cohen report to the Australian Commission on Advanced Education. The issue was in the public as a matter for discussion a decade ago. It was thought to be important then.

It was at that time in 1973 that Professor Alec Lazenby, the then Vice- Chancellor of the University of New England, attempted to bring about the amalgamation of the two higher educational institutions in Armidale. He tried that in 1973. In 1975 and again in 1977 the Australian Universities Commission and the Commission on Advanced Education respectively advocated the strengthening of teacher education by means of a series of amalgamations bringing together small colleges. In 1978 the Tertiary Education Commission predicted the downturn in numbers and needs, and a series of events culminated in our announcement of April 1981. The Commission gave reasons for what it was proposing and why amalgamation was appropriate. The reasons, each one supported, can be grouped.

The first reason was that it believed that larger consolidated institutions are better able to handle the problems associated with change, particularly in circumstances in which resources are not freely available. When there is a constraint on resources they are more able to do this than are single purpose institutions. Of course, single purpose institutions were basically those colleges of advanced education which had been teachers colleges. There are a number of reasons why that is so. The second reason for consolidation advanced by the Commission was that larger consolidated institutions are able to offer students a wider range of educational choices and a higher quality of educational programs. There are a number of reasons why that is so. If necessary I will discuss those reasons.

The third reason-not the only primary reason-was that some economies of scale are to be gained from the establishment of larger institutions. The Commission made it quite clear that significant economies are unlikely in the short run but that administrative overhead is likely to be reduced. The Government accepted those recommendations and that reasoning, and consolidation was recommended for 30 institutions. The Commonwealth expressed broad principles as to how that should be done. We did not lay down in great detail how each institution should go about the rationalisation process. We recognised that arrangements would be made best at the local level and that they might vary to meet the particular circumstances of various institutions. As a result of our approach, satisfactory arrangements have been concluded for 26 of the 30 institutions. They are concluded, they are in place, the dust has settled, for 26 of the 30 institutions. The arrangements vary but all the evidence suggests that they will work well and that higher education in the locations will be strengthened in the long term.

I mentioned a moment ago that several institutions remain. They are the institutions before us tonight in considering the tertiary education Bill. Looking first at Armidale, it is ironical that the greatest determination to refuse to co-operate in implementing the Commonwealth decision occurred at the two institutions at Armidale where just 10 years ago it was clear to most concerned that amalgamation was required. It might interest honourable senators if I quote an extract from the Australian newspaper of 24 January 1973. The headline read: 'University merger plans beaten by politics-Professor'. In that article Professor Alec Lazenby asserted that political considerations had prevented an amalgamation in Armidale. He asserted an amalgamation was necessary and that the educational mission to New England would be set back. The newspaper reported:
Professor Lazenby said the decision was short-sighted and would have far- reaching effects on the State education system and the university itself.
He said-
This is about the decision not to allow amalgamation--
'Had the decision been based on reasonable grounds, I would have accepted it without question.'

He went on and on. At the time that decision was made the Honourable Kim Beazley , the then Commonwealth Minister for Education, criticised New South Wales for not proceeding with that amalgamation. Since 1973 the desire for amalgamation in Armidale has continued. I have been approached by the Pro-Vice-Chancellor of that day, Professor Butland. I have been approached by foundation professors at that University and they have told me that amalgamation was necessary in 1973, that it is necessary now and that in fact it is the intransigence and pride, particularly of a vice-chancellor, that has prevented the parties coming together readily. Against that history and that background, I ask honourable senators to look at what we have sought and to realise that amalgamation was educationally sound 10 years ago, it has been educationally sound since then and still is educationally sound. There has been a decline in full time enrolments at the Armidale College of Advanced Education. That decline has been marked. There has been a 39 per cent drop in full time enrolments in just three or four years. At the nearby University of New England there has been a 27 per cent decline in full time enrolments over the same period. The figures go on. The full time enrolments in those institutions are dropping.

The other city in which the amalgamation has been sought is Newcastle. Here too there has been a decline in full time enrolments. The two institutions are right next door to each other. At the Newcastle College of Advanced Education full time enrolments dropped by 36 per cent from 1978 to 1982. I stress, they dropped by 36 per cent in that time. At the University of Newcastle the drop was 14 per cent in the same period. Those institutions are dropping their full time enrolments. Why would they not amalgamate when it would produce a strengthened institution with greater offerings? Of course, in both those institutions teacher education was the main feature. Teacher education has been diminishing and in both cases the abolition by the New South Wales Government of teacher- trainee scholarships has not helped.
Two other teacher education institutions remain to have amalgamation arrangements announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The IECD will be the first one.
—One of these is the Milperra College of Advanced Education. It serves the south-west area of Sydney.The other is the Hawthorn Institute of Education in Victoria.

—I see that we are getting a rather repetitive interjection. It is clear that special arrangements will be needed to meet the educational needs of south-west Sydney. Using the amalgamation rubric we can see arrangements emerging, in consultation with New South Wales, which will make it possible for an enhanced provision of higher education in the education corridor of south-west Sydney, but we need the amalgamation provisions to bring this about. I have been in recent communication with the State of New South Wales. It too will need special arrangements but it too is moving particularly because there is a deadline for amalgamation.

SPEECH.PARA: Having discussed those amalgamation proposals, I urge honourable senators to consider the way in which we have constructed the Bill. We are confident that amalgamation arrangements will be put in place in all the centres affected. We are confident that we will get assurances to this effect and we are confident that it will be possible to release money to the centres in 1983. I must draw to the attention of honourable senators one other matter. They will know that there is a desire on the Government's part to implement, in co-operation with the States-

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2394), Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, without notice:

I refer to a background report by the Australian Science and Technology Council entitled 'Australian Science and Technology in International Co-operation and Development Assistance.' I ask: What is the nature of the agreement with the Philippines, dated 8 August 1978, relating to co-operation in peaceful uses of nuclear energy and the transfer of nuclear materials? What activities have so far been undertaken? What are presently being undertaken? What authorities, national or international, oversee those activities.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Republic of the Philippines concerning Co-operation in Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy and the Transfer of Nuclear Material is an international treaty. The Agreement was negotiated in accordance with the requirements of the Government' s Nuclear Safeguards Policy announced by the Prime Minister on 24 May 1977. The Agreement was signed on 8 August 1978 and presented in Parliament on 24 August 1978 in accordance with the established practice for such agreements. The statement made by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs provides a full explanation of the Agreement. (See House of Representatives Hansard of 24 August 1978.) The Agreement is one of 10 covering 17 countries making up the present network of Australia's bilateral agreements concerning the peaceful uses of nuclear energy.
On the second and third questions: no activities have taken place under the agreement to date.

On the fourth question: while as yet no activities have been undertaken under the Agreement, it provides that the States which are parties to it accept responsibility in accordance with international law for its implementation and the fulfilment of the obligations contained in it. As in all international agreements the two parties to the Agreement are responsible for overseeing activities undertaken under it. In the case of this Agreement provision is also made for stipulated government authorities to oversee aspects of the activities concerned. In the case of Australia the stipulated governmental authority is the Australian Safeguards Office and in the case of the Philippines the stipulated governmental authority is the Philippines Atomic Energy Commission. The Agreement also recognises that the International Atomic Energy Agency is applying safeguards to such activities in both Australia and the Philippines in accordance with their agreements with the Agency pursuant to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and is supplementary to that asked by Senator Primmer concerning the general question of aid to the Philippines in the light of its treatment of an Australian national, Father Gore. I ask: Given the pattern of harassment, planting of evidence, concoction of charges and idenfinite detention by the military and its lackeys, of which Father Gore is only the latest victim, will the Australian government immediately terminate any assistance to the Philippines military which is running at the rate of over $1,343,000 this year. Can the Minister explain why the Australian taxpayer should fund even partially a corrupt and brutual military regime which thereby has more of its own money to spend on the suppression of the poor, the oppressed and the downtrodden of that sad nation?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to that part of the honourable senator's question dealing with military aid:

Australian military assistance to the Philippines is part of the Australian Government's Defence Co-operation Program with countries of South East Asia, Papua New Guinea and the South West Pacific which is designed to develop the capacity for self-reliance of countries in areas of strategic importance to Australia who share our strategic concerns.
By contributing to regional stability we also assist in providing conditions which are conducive to peaceful national development.

The program is weighted towards activities that develop defensive rather than offensive capabilities and which assist neighbours to acquire technical and managerial skills which the Australian Services are well-equipped to provide.

Successive Australian Governments have recognised that the Defence Co- operation Program is important to Australian defence objectives and accorded them commensurate priority. Co-operation programs with the Philippines have run continuously since 1973. Such co-operation, whilst serving the interests of both parties, clearly does not imply on the part of either endorsement of any or all of the other's policies.
